column1: My faaave deep dish in chicago with an N of two. The crust is super buttery and less soggy more crispy than other deep dish I've tried. Pizza pie was my favorite. Pro tip, you can order take out and eat at the BYOP (bring your own pizza) bar and library across the street.  If you're traveling to chicago and can only try one deep dish spot, this is it!!

Finally got to try Pequod's, service was a 3 and the pizza was a 5. To my taste, it was way better  than pizza's from usual Chicago chains. I went there on a  Friday around 2pm and was super happy to not have to wait hours to get a table. Regarding the restaurant, it looks like a dark dive bar, nothing fancy. We didn't get explanation for the menu (it would have been appreciated). Basically you get to choose between 3 regular pizzas and then you can add as many toppings as you want (for an additional charge). I like they have a caramelized crust. You're going for a deep dish, so get your table before you're starving because it takes a long time to cook haha! as delicious warmed up in the oven the next day! I got a salad to wait, it was okay, it comes with a plastic cup of red vinegar and another one of olive oil, not the best one though. As far of the pizza, the ingredients were fresh, the dough was good and we got some to go! (We were so hungry we forgot to take a pic of it) I'll go back but probably to take out.
Easily the best deep dish in Chicago!I don't have much more to add to this page but I will recommend getting extra sauce and extra cheese....it really makes a difference!

This style deep dish is the thick crust pan style pizza, even though it wasn't the super cheesy topped off with sauce on top that I assumed all Chicago deep dish was this is still some really good pizza.The restaurant itself is kind of a dive sports bar, lots of seating & lots of tv, a good variety of beers & appetizers to go with the pizza selection.

First time having deep dish pizza!Wonderful place -- didn't have to wait too long and the service was so nice! Gave us a great recommendation for pizza and was so friendly!We got one of the custom deep dish ones and shared among three people. We got the smallest size and we still couldn't finish it. Would definitely say its a great bargain for the price and would warn you to not underestimate their food. We also shared some wings, which I loved as well.Definitely recommend!

I tried lou malnatis while in chicago and I preferred pequodsLou malnatis fell short for mebut pequods was greatit was only about a 10minute waitbut a 40minute wait for the pizza to come outthe sauce was so good!! and the caramelized/burnt cheese crust was greatgot a large and i only ended up being able to finish one slicetook home the leftovers but the pizza still tasted great after

Pequod's does not have any pre-made signature pizza toppings like the other popular deep dish spots; instead, all of their pizzas are customizable. With this said, they do not allow pre-ordering your pizza while waiting for your table (probably to ensure you don't skip town, but why would you?!) When my friend and I arrived at 6:30pm on a Saturday, the placed was completely packed. There was a 90 minute wait for us, but luckily we found two stools at the bar instead.Since we knew how heavy the pizza was about to be, we started off with a house salad with italian dressing ($4.80). After over an hour later, our small size pan pizza ($11.75) finally arrived. We also added italian beef (+$2.75) and mushrooms (+$1.85) inside too. The pizza was nicely done and that first slice was delicious. All of the ingredients were stuffed into the cheese and marinera sauce being held together in a crunchy crust. As much as I wanted to finish both of my slices, I only got through my second slice halfway. The special part about Pequod's is its customization (you can even do half and half on the pizza to make everyone in the party happy). But because of this, they also take much longer. Thankfully I was not too hungry or else my patience would have truly been tested here. Although Pequod's is a bit further outside of Chicago, it's still worth the trek over here --but I'd definitely recommend coming here at odd hours to shorten the wait time.

During a weeklong work trip in Chicago, I knew my co-worker and I had to eat deep dish at one point during the week. I mentioned to our client that we were thinking of Lou Malnati's, and he basically persuaded us to go to Pequod's instead. In his words, "Lou Malnati's is good; Pequod's is great."We arrived around 8PM on a Tuesday, and the place was packed! We got a pager, sat outside to look at the menu, and our pager buzzed within a few minutes. Since it was just us 2, we decided on a small pan pizza with bell peppers and Canadian bacon as toppings (bell peppers were extra topping; Canadian bacon was half extra). Honestly I loved the fact that they offered half toppings because sometimes two people just can't get along! But in this case, my co-worker was vegetarian but I knew I needed some meat.I know there's nothing like Chicago deep dish, and this experience reiterated that. I did feel like the crust was a little thick, but it didn't really change what I thought about the pizza. The crust was AMAZING!! I looked forward to that extra crunch with every slice I ate (I only ate 2).We had zero regrets changing our plans from Lou Malnati's to Pequod's. The World Series was on, and it honestly felt like a place where the locals go. I would absolutely come here again!

Awesome deep dish pizza, atmosphere and if possible even better service!  Called ahead and although they do not take reservations will take priority seating.  Good news there, it cut our wait from 60 to 30 minutes.  Plenty of room next door at the Whale Tail for a drink before dinner.  Beeper so we knew when table was ready.  True Chicago style deep dish with a crisp bottom crust.  Delicious!  Staff was running but didn't miss a beat on low drinks and rapid refills.  Appreciated the management sign on graffiti on the walls but only added to the ambiance of a unique location!

To my knowledge there are pretty much three iconic Chicago foods, Italian beef, a Chicago hot dog and deep dish pizza.  Of the three, the pizza was the one I had the least interest in trying while we were in town vacationing.  I've had them in various forms before, at an Uno's franchise in NC, Lou Malnati's delivered frozen to cook at home.  You could argue that those are not "original" in one way or another but whatever...  I've always been underwhelmed.Still, when in Chicago it seemed somehow wrong not to get deep dish one day so after a Cub's comeback win at Wrigley we went to Pequod's which was my choice after much Yelp research and a couple sightings on Food Network.  The draw to me was the ring of caramelized cheese around the top of the crust.  What an awesome choice it was and not just because of the delicious cheesy ring.  The entire pizza was outstanding. The crust (thick but not too thick, crispy but not greasy) sausage and pepperoni (tasty and plenty of it) and sauce (just pure tomato goodness) made for a really, really good meal.  The ability to get personal sized pizzas made it easy for me to get the meat fest and my wife to get just cheese so no need to even compromise!I guess you can call me a convert and Pequod's gets all the credit.  Oh yeah, we had some buffalo wings before the pizza and they were good as well.

The last time I was in Chicago and had deep-dish pizza, I got food poisoning (thanks, Lou Malnati's!  Never again!)  But, my cousin really wanted to try some Chicago-style pizza while we were in town for the Chicago Marathon, so I acquiesced on the conditions that 1) we only ate the pizza AFTER the marathon and 2) we ate anywhere BUT Lou Malnati's.After doing some research, we settled on Pequod's and took a taxi over to Chicago's North Side to stuff our faces after finishing the race.  It was about 2 PM when we showed up and this place was PACKED!  Fortunately, we were able to grab a table for two immediately.  As an FYI: Pequod's bakes their pizzas from scratch, and since it's a pan pizza, it takes a bit longer to cook (about 40 minutes), so if you're HANGRY, it's better to call in your order ahead of time by phone.To stave off the runger, we ordered a sampler of their Appetizer Combo, which featured fried mushrooms, jalapeno poppers, mozzarella sticks, and fried zucchini bites.  I'm not gonna lie, this was pretty unremarkable and not worth writing about, but we were starving and needed something to tide us over til the pizza arrived.When our pizza pie finally got delivered, I could not WAIT to dig in!  Technically, pan pizza is different than deep-dish, but Pequod's pizza is still an experience you can really only find in Chicago.  It features a thick crust with slightly burnt edges ("caramelized," as the restaurant calls it) and layers of cheese and sauce, with your choice of toppings piled on (we chose sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms, and peppers).While my first experience with deep dish at Lou Malnati's left me unimpressed, I really enjoyed the pan pizza at Pequod's.  The crust was thick without being too doughy, and sturdy enough to hold up to all the sauce and cheese without becoming soggy.  The caramelized burnt edges added a nice crunchy texture.  The ingredients tasted fresh and they did NOT skimp on the amount of toppings!  The sauce tasted very tomatoey (in a good way) and not canned.Also, this pizza is FILLING.  Two hungry dudes who had just run 26.2 miles couldn't even finish all six slices of their medium sized pizza.  So come hungry, and bring plenty of friends!OVERALL: 4/5.  Skip the appetizers and go straight for their famous pan pizza.  It's rich, delicious, and worth every single calorie and clogged artery.  I'm sure both NYC and Chicago-style purists can agree that the pizza at Pequod's is darn good!

Ordered Pequod's for delivery to our hotel after a long day of traveling. They estimated 2 hours for delivery but it actually came in 1.5 hours which was nice. The pizza was just okay for me. I think I would like to try the thin crust next time. If I were a fan of deep dish, this would be great. They definitely don't skimp on the toppings which is nic

Detroit style pizza disguised as Chicago style pizza lol. Pizza is really good thought. Definitely five stars for sure. I called in my pizza and it still took every bit of one hour so be prepared to wait or call it in like I did. Price: They have an amazing lunch special for 5-6 bucks that comes with a drink. I mean that is such a steal! Really good quality pizza for less that ten dollars. It's very filling as well. I was completely full of the person loan pizza special. Food: they call it Chicago style pizza but this reminds me a lot of Detroit style pizza. When I think of Chicago pizza I think of Lou malnatis or Giordano's. Pequod's is a fusion of Chicago meets Detroit. The caramelized crust is something Detroit is know for. I don't think any other Chicago pizza place does their crust like this. I personally love it! Also the bread is very thick with just a little bit of cheese and sauce on top. Check mark  Detroit style pizza. The sauce is a little on the tangy side. Still really good. Glad I was able to get it.  Reminded me a lot of via 313 out of Austin Texas (via 313 is from Detroit) As of right star pizza in Houston Texas makes the best deep fish Chicago pizza I've ever had. The owners are from Chicago. Look them up. Also Windy City pizza in antascacita Texas is number 2. Owner is from Chicago. If you are ever in Houston, try those two out.

Came here as part of a Chicago pizza tour, was not disappointed. This is one of the 3 main styles of "Chicago-style" pizza (in order of thickness, thick to slim): Deep Dish, Pan, Tavern.The pizza here is pan.It's thick, but it's not "wedding cake" thick like some of the deep dish can be.The main star of this pizza was the sausage.  It was perfectly spiced.  It made you think "what's in this?" in a good way.Service was excellent and beer selection was above average.  Ambiance was like that of a normal, divey bar that has been around for a long time, which I liked.

When in Chicago, one MUST have deep dish. It just ain't right if you leave the city without tucking into their specialty.Since I've already had Lou Malnati's, I really wanted to try something different this time around. Some quick googling told me Pequod's was THE place for deep dish so off we went. The four of us showed up around lunchtime on a Saturday and were promptly seated. The space is like a no-frills divey bar filled with tchotchkes and old, worn booths. Staff was super friendly and really made us feel welcome.We ended up waiting about 45mins for a large pizza stuffed with pepperoni, sausage, olives, mushrooms and bell peppers. This baby was FILLING and the caramelized crust was amazing and so freakin' crispy! It was everything deep dish should be; gooey, hearty, and packed with fillings. Each of us ended up eating a slice and we took two to go. TL;DR Fantastic pizza. Just go.

When visiting Chicago, we visited quite a few Chicago pizza joints and Pequod's was by far our favorite. Pequod's is where the locals go is what we were told, which seemed very true once walking in. It's like your neighborhood sports bar. The pizza here is a pan pizza and not so much a stuffed pizza like some other places. It's got a thick crust with caramelized cheese on the edges, a very delightful sauce, and fresh toppings.  I absolutely loved every bite of this pizza and wish my hometown had something similar. If you're a local, I'm sure you already know about Pequod's. If you're a tourist, make sure you make Pequod's your first pizza stop.

Met up with my husband for a quick lunch date. We ordered the lunch special of the personal pizza and pop for $5! Can't beat that deal. It was my first time here and I am a fan. I love the burnt cheese on the edges! Prob cut and burnt my mouth since I have zero patience once my pizza gets to the table. We also ordered the jalapeño poppers which were basic but always good. Will def be back whenever I am in the area!

I came here with a few friends with the goal of finally trying out some of Chicago's deep-dish pizza. This place serves pan pizza but based on the way service explained it, this pretty much still counts.This place has a bar and a lot of appetizer options in addition to the pizza. Pan pizza takes a long time to make, but if you get an appetizer and a few drinks, the time will fly by. The fries are delicious and from what I've seen, the appetizers come in awesome portion sizes, so it's definitely worth your buck.The pan pizza coming felt like an early Christmas gift. There is a LOT of pizza and the service helped us by cutting and plating it for us. We got a couple of vegetable toppings on one half and regular cheese on the other half. It turned out to be absolutely delicious and filling. Definitely worth a try and absolutely worth it.Considering that each slice of pan pizza is basically 2 pizza slices equivalent of food, the price is amazing if you split it among a few people. This place is also open pretty late, so this could make for good pregame or post-game food, depending on how you go about your night.Overall, fantastic experience. Definitely check this place out if you're in the area.

Damn good pizza!  All you need to order is a large deep dish sausage and you are good!  The carmelized crust is outstanding!  If you don't like this pizza, stay home with your frozen pizzas and thin crust appetizers!Get here early, it's packed every night from 6 to 9.Service is good, it's also a Nebraska Cornhusker bar which is a shame.

Pequod's was the first stop on our epic Chicago Pizza Tour, where we were introduced to our first #pizzastyle: pan pizza. And oh, was it delicious. We were each served a huge, thick slice of their pepperoni and sausage pie, with its hearty layer of house-made red sauce, gooey melted cheese, and topped with amazing meat. Especially the sausage. Omg, that sausage. It was so good I'm seriously considering booking the next flight back to O'Hare. The restaurant had set aside a special seating area just for our group, which was a nice perk of being on the tour cuz this place was hopping. We also got some drinks, and I chose a local beer. Which was sort of a mistake, considering the size of the pizza. The beer was good but I was only able to drink about half of it due to the yummy pizza filling my tummy.  The service was also super friendly, they didn't seem annoyed by us as some restaurants can when you go on one of these food tours.  They were also very efficient, as we were served right away and were able to eat and drink and be out of there in about 30 minutes so we could be off to our next stop. I will definitely return here on my next trip, whenever that may be!

Okay I'M SAYING IT. This is the best deep dish in Chicago.We got the pepperoni and sausage medium, and it was everything I would ever want it to be. The crust, the sauce to cheese ratio, the amount of pepperoni on each slice... I'm still dreaming about it.I called in the order ahead of time, and they wouldn't put it in the oven until we were seated - which confused me. Why would I bother calling in ahead of time when I can just order at the table for the same amount of time? Don't see why that is an option. We still waited 30 min for the pizza. It is so out of my way, but I will definitely be back.

Pequod's was my first ever deep dish and it was sooo good! I went here on my first trip to Chicago with a group of girls and we deliberated over which pizza place to try. Pequod's won and I'm glad they did! We stopped in around 4pm on a Saturday and they were busy but not slammed. We were able to get a table right away. Note that you will still wait 45 minutes for your pizza. It takes some time for them to caramelize the crust and this is what sets Pequod's apart. We ordered two pies for 5 people and we still had leftovers. Deep dish is filling but we also had late dinner reservations so we didn't want to eat too much. I ate the veggie deep dish and it was so good! The crust was hearty and delicious and the cheese was everything. I would like to try a couple of other deep dish spots for the sake of comparison but I can't imagine it getting much better. The service was good and the atmosphere is lively but laid back. I am not sure what part of town we were in because we took a Lyft and I wasn't paying attention. I think this is the only location, though. I would definitely recommend!

I may not be from a place that is known for any famous pizza and I am normally a NY style fan...but Pequod's turned me into a deep dish fan as well...BUT as long as it's from here! Peqoud's was our 2nd deep dish place and it blew our minds away. We went on an off time (around 2-3pm) on a Sunday but there was still a little wait (about 15-20 minutes) so we wanted to save time and instead grabbed 2 empty seats at the bar since we know we also have to wait another 45 minutes for the pizza to be cooked. We ordered a small pepperoni and sausage deep dish to share. The crust is covered in melted cooked cheese- which gave the crust a great crunch. The small deep dish was enough for 2 of us. They loaded and I mean loaded the pizza with pepperoni and sausage! And the best thing, it was probably high quality meats because it was not greasy at all. The sausage was probably the best I had on a pizza. The tomato sauce wasn't too sweet or sour, it was the right cooked down tangy flavor. Also, the crust was not hard as a rock, instead was the right softness and hardness. We enjoyed every last bite...

I can see why this place has such a huge cult following. Great deep dish pizzas that have a slight char on the outside, descent priced drinks and a relaxing and chaotic atmosphere. The wait was like 45 minutes to get a table but luckily I was allowed to squeeze into the bar and skipped all the wait. Still, call ahead if you can or just don't come starving. It's worth the wait if you have to.

I've been so excited to try this place for years.  I've been on the hunt for a similar go to for deep dish! We got here after a walking tour ended and were seated quickly!  The tables and chairs are old and my chair was even taped up.  It looks very aged. I'm so glad we got there early because when we left there was a 45 minute wait.We quickly knew what we wanted (Sausage and pepperoni pizza), and I ordered a beer and my husband ordered a diet drink. The pizza came out about 35 minutes later, which was what we anticipated.  I was very excited for the cheese pull when she served us our slices but there was barely one.  Note: next time I'll order extra cheese.  However, there were a lot of toppings and I still really loved this pizza it just wasn't like the videos I've seen before. One thing to note, when the bill came it "suggested" tips on the iPad; however, it was based on the subtotal plus tax rather than the sub-total... I have to say that was a bit shady to me, as sales tax is over 10% in Chicago and is not supposed to be included as part of tipping and I bet most customers don't even pay attention to this. There is an option to change your tip to a different percentage or dollar amount, but you have to notice what is happening.  I hope this gets changed. I'd like to give them another try when we visit the city again.

Bam!  Quality Chicago style deep dish pizza!  Although I ordered it to go and had to wait 25 minutes until I got to my hotel, it was still delicious and the crust was crispy.  I got the pepperoni and sausage pizza.  The ingredients were fresh and plentiful.  Careful what size you order as this pizza is satisfying and filling.  This is a must stop by place if you are in Chicago.  Don't miss the opportunity to have the best Chicago style deep dish in the country.  Even if you don't like deep dish, give this one a try.  You will be

I wish I could give a 5 for food and 2 for customer service....The hostess station was a HOT MESS when we got there around 7:30 pm on Saturday.  We expected to have a wait, but not a 2.5 hour one!  That just seems like poor management and overall time management!  It made it extremely frustrating to listen to the hostess tell guest after guest 2-2.5 hour wait when I was looking at 3 empty tables within sight of the entrance!  Lucky, we were able to grab 2 seats at the bar and order right from there.  The bartender was working like crazy to not only serve her guests by run the bar for the entire place.  It was quite disappointing to see 2 staff members standing on their phone the ENTIRE time we sat at the bar....how is there a 2.5 hour wait but not all hands on deck?The pizza was a great and we'd go back for more!  CAREFUL....don't over order.  The small was plenty for 2 people!

I have been wanting to come here for 4 YEARS. Don't be dumb like me and wait that long. My husband and I went in for dinner earlier in the week before a movie at Webster Place. Since it was  a weekday, there was no wait. But I know for sure there is usually a long wait for a  table at high traffic times. We ordered onion rings and a medium sausage pizza. I thought to myself, maybe the hype isn't real. OH IT REAL. The crust of the pizza is so good, it's worth it. For sure try this if you haven't already.  The onion rings we perfect, I like that it's served wit bbq sauce.  I can't wait to go back. The service is quick and the prices are fair.

Pequod's.  Strange name, delicious pizza.I'm not certain why the whale on the menu is wearing thong underwear on its head, but I do know that the pizza is fantastic.The atmosphere is that of a college pizza/sports bar.  A majority of it's patrons seem to be college students.  I felt like an old geezer, and I'm only 40. This place is extremely busy, and the line was out the door...on a Sunday afternoon.  Thankfully our pizza tour was able to walk right in, as they were expecting us.  I felt bad for the people waiting outside in the sun!Their deep dish has a lighter, airy crust, but very thick.  When you add the cheese and sauce, you get a very unique type of pizza.Oh, and do yourself a favor - EAT ALL OF THE CRUST.  It looks burnt, but that's the best part -  "carmelized crust."  It's a layer of cheese that melts together with the crust.  A tiny piece of heaven right there!I probably won't ever be in this neighborhood again, but if I am, I'll definitely drop in!

Well worth the wait!  Even with the plethora of tables upstairs and downstairs, be prepared to wait awhile.  However, the service is excellent and the deep dish is in a class of its own.  The burnt cheese up the back of the crust just makes this the best place for Chicago pie, hands down.

By far the best pizza in Chicago! A month ago I met a guy in an Uber we shared in San Diego and directed me to Pequod's staying this is where Chicagoans frequent and boy I'm glad I met him. This was the best pizza I've tried in my 4 visits to Chicago and will only eat pizza there from now on. Decor-it's an old brick building with two floors of dining and a bar on both floors. The walls have a mix of Chicago sports paraphanelia and Chicago history. Tight seating area upstairs and down, and a very small bar upstairs. Service-I sat at the bar, so really can't comment on service, but bar tender was decent and brought me what I asked. Food-Pizza is Phenomenal!!!! Perfectly seasoned with a blend of spices like oregano and garlic. The crust was crisped to perfection and topped with tons of cheese, sausage, and pepperoni's. Garlic cheese bread was also perfection! Simply put this place rocks and is amazing. Beware there are long lines, but that is testament of how good food is. Can't wait to go back!!!

I am a lover of thin crust!!!Having said that, never ever eat thin crust here..it's sad..and a pathetic excuse for pizza BUT...The deep dish here is SO yummy. I love the sausage here even though I usually avoid sausages (colon cancer and all, blah blah). Simply put, this place is an exception for me. I eat a deep dish pizza with sausage here!! Totes breaking away from my usual preferences. Try it yourself. You might surprise yourself too!

I visited the Morton Grove location 8 years ago and I absolutely loved it.  I still enjoyed the pizza at this newer Chicago location, but it didn't taste quite as amazing at the one I had at the Morton Grove location.  The crust seemed more burnt than the caramelized crust I remember.  Maybe it's because the Morton Grove location is the original, and the oven used has the special flavor from years of baking pizza. One tip if you plan to eat lunch on a weekday - call in your order.  Then text them when you are 15 minutes away.  They will reserve your seat and your pizza will come out in about 15-20 minutes after you are seated.
Ever since I've been to Burt's place in Skokie I've lovers pequods the place is bustling as busy sometimes a wait but worth it. I love sausage mushroom onion a little well done yum

My sister used to live in Chicago, and being from NY, she was super excited to experience their pizza.  I don't remember the name of the place she took us to for deep dish, but none of us liked it --- the sauce, the crust, the cheese... none of it.  I want to say it was Giordano's, but I'm not 100% sure.Fast forward to now, I returned to Chicago for a festival and was willing to give pizza another chance.  I tried Lou Malnati's, and while I liked the sauce and cheese, I was not a fan of the crust at all.  But then after the festival I decided to seek this place out... and everything changed.  First of all, there was a mob outside of the restaurant waiting to be seated.  Since I was by myself, I was happy to squeeze through, go inside and find a seat at the bar.  As I passed by the hostess's podium, I saw a sign that said pizzas ordered at the time would take 60 minutes.  That's a nice thing to know, instead of being shocked as you wait for your food.Anyways, I found a seat at the bar and ordered a glass of wine as I waited for pizza.  I believe it did take about an hour, and when it came... it was pipin' hot in a pan.  The person who brought it to me cut me a slice and put it on a plate.  I had to wait for it to cool down before I could pick it up.  As a matter of fact, it was still a tad loose so I knifed & forked it.  I asked for pepperoni and green peppers, but I did not expect it to be huge chunks of peppers nor for there to be loads and loads of pepperoni.  That combined with their rather sweet sauce and perfectly caramelized and textured crust was....AWESOME!!!Chicago pizza has been redeemed for me and it's all thanks to Pequod's.   I would gladly come back.  Be warned: do NOT come with a big party.  I get the feeling you'd be waiting a long time if you did.  If you do though, just be prepared.

A deep dish pizza unlike anything I've eaten before.Recommend by a couple of local Chicago friends, we decided to stop in. Upon entering, there's a written sign showing you the expected wait for your pizza. When we walked in it showed an estimated 40 minute wait. Our party was 5 & the server recommended a large pizza but to be honest a medium would've been sufficient.I can't compare their deep dish to any pizza, I've eaten before. It tasted more similar to a gourmet lasagna & it was excellent. The crust was the highlight and the toppings (pepperoni, sausage) were excellent as well. Overall it was very good but not great. A unique tasting pizza.

I love Pequod's, and always recommend it to visitors looking for good deep dish. It's my second favorite deep dish in the city (after Art of Pizza), but hands down has my favorite crust. The caramelized cheese is delicious, and worth coming for on its own. I especially like the spinach pies here. As a note, you can call ahead for preferred seating. If you have a large group, they'll guarantee a table.
Came by here looking for the unique deep dish. The place is mobbed with locals. Service was fast and attentive. The deep dish was tasty, love the way they do the crust here with crunch.

Real Chicagoans know: this is the best Chicago pie there is. They've been using the same pans for like 100 years, so every pizza tells the story of pizzas past. The way the cheese caramelizes around the edges is just perfection, I don't know how else to describe it.

After doing a search on Yelp for the best pizza in Chicago, we knew we had to give Pequod's a try. Staying downtown, the walk was too far, so we took a Lyft (which was a quick ride). We arrived around 6pm on a Wednesday and were seated immediately. Upon entry, it seemed a bit crowded, so I was pleased when we were led upstairs to a much more open space. We were directed to a high-top table and our server quickly welcomed us. Now, this place is all about the pizza, so I will get to the point. It was interesting that the pie was not a traditional Chicago-style pizza, but a deep dish pizza, so the main difference was the crust. That fact threw me a bit at first, but the pizza was tremendously satisfying. The pepperoni was thick and spicy, the sauce flavorful, and the cheese perfectly melted and rich. We ordered a small. It had four pieces, but they were substantial, so between the two of us, we ate three and took one to go. Our server was super friendly and attentive (not too much attention, not too little attention, but the attention was just right). If you are visiting Chicago, I recommend venturing out of downtown proper to taste the deliciousness of Pequod's.

4.5 stars. Yum! Tried Pequod's after it was recommended to us by a few people. Arrived at 11:15am on a Sunday morning and there were maybe 4 people in the place - wanted to be sure we got there early to get a seat. We had done the priority seating on their website the day before, but turns out we didn't need it. Since there was plenty of room, we decided to sit at the bar. We ordered a small pizza (this for my husband and I) with sausage, garlic onions, tomatoes, and extra cheese and sauce (as recommended by fellow Yelpers). I'm definitely glad we got the extra cheese - I'm not sure I'd get the extra sauce if I had to do it again (I'd also definitely forego the tomatoes, definitely unnecessary, especially with the extra sauce). The crust - ooooh, that crust. Just as good as everyone says. The roasted garlic was amazing, the cheese nice and gooey. Overall...it was like pizza lasagna - and I mean that very positively. Really delicious, and filling. The small was perfect for the two of us (we're from out of town, so no place to store leftovers). The bartender was honest and said it takes about 40 minutes per pizza, so we split a cesar salad...if I had to do it all over again I wouldn't have ordered that, I would have just waited. Why not 5 stars? It's a bit expensive (I mean, it's pizza...and I wish there'd been a few more pieces of sausage). And there weren't very many beers on tap. I know their focus is pizza, but a few more beers (and local beers) would have been nice to see.
The best pizza ever in a relaxed atmosphere...functional wait service...relaxed ambiance

Only the long wait for a table keeps a fifth star from appearing in this review.  We were in town for a wedding and wanted to sample what Chicago calls pizza.  We were directed fortunately to Pequod's and were not disappointed.  To cut our wait time we ate at the bar.  Our bar tender was very helpful as we discussed our ordering options.  It's a fun environment and the pizza was delicious.

After a full day of being at the United Center for my first time in Chicago, and obstinately not eating much, I obviously had to get myself some deep dish pizza. Pequod's was highly recommended to me, and I got there past midnight on a Friday night.Since I was there at a relatively odd hour, getting a spot was a breeze. The ambience is similar neighborhood friendly dive bar but with the aroma of pizzas instead of beer. To my dismay though, the only pizzas served here were pan pizzas - the horror!On clarifying with the waitress though, it seems like the main difference between a deep dish and their pan pizzas is the fact that Pequod's makes them in a skillet, resulting in their (famous) blackened edges. I ended up going with a simple if slightly oddball combo of olives and jalepenos.It had all the hallmarks of a deep dish pizza: 40min to make; a fork and knife needed to eat it and being absolutely stuffed after about 2 slices. It was absolutely delicious! The ingredients tasted so fresh, and the balance of cheese:toppings:crust seemed perfect; with nothing overwhelming the pizza. I love my Brooklyn style pizza, but Pequod's is right up there with the best I've ever had and I can't wait for another trip to Chicago to have it!

I've been to Chicago twice. Over the course of those two trips, I have had Lou Malnati's, Giodarno's, and Pequod's on this most recent trip. I will rank them accordingly: 1) Giodarno's2) Pequod's3) Malnati's On to Pequod's deep dish. We walked in right when it opened, so there wasn't a wait and got seated fairly quickly. We ordered and customized toppings (peppers, onions, and sausage). Pequod's is well known for their caramelized crust so I was very excited to try that. When the pizza, came it smelled delicious and looked so good. Flavors were very good, but I honestly was not a fan of the caramelized crust on some parts. It was kind of burned, so it added this unpleasant taste when eating it. We also ordered fried mushrooms as apps, also good, but could skip especially if you get deep dish. Worth checking out if you're in the area, but it's kinda tough because it's not super convenient to get to.

So before my trip to Chicago I was doing A LOT of research. I've been to the Chi a lot now. But I never really cared about who was the best deep dish in town. I was only interested in experiencing it and the Chi Town lifestyle, if you know what I mean. So this time I wanted to know who had the best in town. During my research this place kept on popping up. I've already tried a lot of the other top rated places so wanted to go here. Food Network also rated it the second best pizza in the Nation! So I had to give it a try.When I went I ordered a large pep and sausage pan (deep dish) w/ extra cheese. It came out in the normal deep dish cast iron pan. And you could tell just by looking at it what time of experience I was in for. It looked so good. When I finally started eating it I fell in love. No joke, it's that good. All the flavors go so well together. The sauce was perfect and everything came together. I love the darkened caramelized cheese ring around the edges. You won't really get that anywhere else and it's kind of a Peqouds "thing". This was my first deep dish with thick crust. But it was so good. It was cooked perfect. The pizza was steaming hot and I still couldn't even let it sit a second before taking more bites. I will say this I by far my favorite Deep Dish. Giordano's what? Lou Malnati's who?... never heard of em..... This is my go to spot in my favorite city now. No game or gimmicks, you gotta go if you never been. This pizza is LIT.The place is very small. And I heard that it normally has lines around the corner. So I made sure to get here early before opening to get a spot. I'd suggest that for anyone that comes from out of town. The inside looks like a plain regular bar or pub. Which makes it even better. They don't have that corporate feel that the other places have. Their menu is basic, like super basic. And that just adds to the whole ambiance of this place. No flashing likes and smoke and mirrors. They are about their pizza, and that's what on show here.The service was nice. Nothing too great. Just average. But that's fine. As long as it is not negative. Everything was on time and quick. We had our drinks refilled when we needed them and everything. Overall this place has set the standard for Chicago deep dish for me. I was giving other pizza places high ratings. But not I gotta re think the whole thing. This place is a 10/10 and everything else falls under it. That's just #Facts. This is definitely my new go to when in the Windy City. I'd recommend this to anybody that. Tourist or not.  Wish I could give it 6 stars honestly.

Best deep dish pizza I've ever had. Crust was buttery, sauce was perfect and the cheese was piled high. The wait time to get seated was not bad at all. The cooking time for the pizza was about 1 hour if not longer which is why I'm not giving them 5 stars. They need to figure out a better system to get the food out quicker. An hour is just way too long.

This was our first stop on an incredible Pizza Tour of Chicago that we took on a work trip recently. I have seriously been dreaming about this pizza ever since.The place feels kind of divey, but they are doing some transcendental magic in the kitchen. Our tour guide explained that they add mozzarella in the cast iron pan to help create their incredible caramelized, crunchy, unforgettable crust. I am such a sucker for burnty cheese, and their toppings are as incredibly well-made as their signature crest. Be sure to order the Italian sausage.I really intended to save more room for the last stop, a deep dish spot that I expected to like the best, but Pequod's was truly the stand out of the tour. After finishing my own piece, I scavenged off of some of my coworkers plates who hadn't had room to finish their whole piece. Even our gluten-free gal was picking the cheesy edge off of other people's pieces so that she could participate vicariously in this incredible pizza.I so highly recommend this spot and guarantee I'll be back again and again!

If you can't decide where to get deep dish pizza in Chicago, give this place a try. It's not the Chicago deep dish I remember having as a kid, but it's pretty damn good. The crust is thick and a little bread-y, the toppings are fresh and not over cooked. I got a small to share with one person and it was just the right amount of food. It takes about 40 minutes for them to cook the pizza but we seemed to have only waited 20. If you're driving, there's plenty of street parking nearby. I got here around 12:30pm on a Saturday and didn't have to wait for a table. Although I do have to dock some points for the state of the table. Which had to be propped up so our pizza didn't meet an untimely demise. Great place to catch a game too, there's plenty of TVs for you to catch your favourite sports teams.

Tourist alert:  Do not eat here!  Go to UNO's or Geno's East.  Please!!  That way we won't have to wait as long for a table and this fantastic pizza when we go back (and back).  Friendly staff kept our drinks filled while we snacked on cheese sticks (just OK) waiting the announced 55 min wait for the pies. They came a bit early and we loved them!  Especially the deep dish.  We found the thin crust to be a bit thick for our liking, but learning for next time.  Generous amounts of toppings!

We were sitting quietly in a booth on the second story of Pequod's near midnight. Princess Carewee was to my left, configuring her camera after a full day of adventure. Across from us is our mercurial friend, Kent24, fully wrapped in Giants attire. We were quiet. Battered from a long day of eating, drinking, baseball, and more eating, we had to travel by foot to this popular Pizza place. There was little energy left for idle conversations.By contrast, the restaurant was loud and lively, even at this late hour. The walls were illuminated with neon lights of commercial beer logos and Chicago sports team. Against the dim lighting, the décor reminds one more of a sports bar than a pizzeria. But maybe the two are the same here in the Midwest. The menu was a single laminated piece of literature. It dutifully reminded us that Pequod was famous for its caramelized crust, or its "darkened edge". Between the three of us, we had no idea how this would taste, but were in firm agreement that it must be awesome. The menu also listed out all the toppings that we can choose from. The usual suspects were all present: Spinach, Sausage, Mushroom, Extra Ch---"Extra Cheese." I broke our silence with a wide-eyed whisper. Kent24 was not having it. Still feeling the effects of our hearty dinner not so many hours ago, the proposition of adding another layer of fat to an already heavy fourth-meal must have sounded ludicrous. But the thing you have to know about Kent24 is that it's never a 'hard no.' As a matter of fact, the 'No' is merely an invitation to strengthen the proposal of your idea - to describe the insanity, to explain the improbability, and to illustrate the grandeur of its effects. Kent24's 'No' is merely the demand that you verbalize the "Lit-Ness" that is your idea and immortalize the awesomeness in words."Fine, get the extra cheese." Kent24 conceded, inevitably I may add.Thus, I would not be doing our gluttonous gluttony justice if I do not chronicle our pizza experience to you as I have imagined it to Kent24 just moments before our glory.The server arrived at our table with a circular pan. Sitting within the pan were the dear and familiar colors of a midnight pizza. The crimson red of the classic pepperoni and the radiant green of the bell peppers clashed violently against a wobbly backdrop of golden mozzarella. Fiery red tomato sauces burst through pockets of the melted surface and splattered on any and all nearby darkened sausages and olives. All the colors glistened under a thin layer of oil, accentuating this visual spectacle. Enclosed within the pan was chaos and beauty, and it was announcing its presence ever so loudly with its violent aroma. My heart began racing. I knew Kent24's was too. After juggling our phones with our trembling hands, we had the cameras in position to capture this moment. Finally, a LITsperience worthy to share on our social media outlets, guaranteed to extract those coveted little hearts from our followers.The server, standing by us this whole time, motioned politely for us to wait. He wore a slight smirk on his face and his brown eyes exude the type of confidence that we had only seen in a meme... he did not speak, but we heard him loud and clear."This isn't even my final form."The metal slicer clanged against the pan and in one swift motion, raised a slice of the pie into the night sky. The sight was majestic --- no, it was divine. In its ascent, small pieces of sausages separated from its body and fell gloriously from the skies. The streams of mozzarella stretched with the crust and into the gates of heaven. Each golden strand looked as if it were a celestial ray of light breaking through the clouds and onto Earth, blessing the taste buds of devout eaters.  In truth, neither Kent24 nor I finished more than one slice of that pizza. As its appearance suggests, it was as heavy as it was filling. We were punished for our greed and gluttony as we had no microwave in our lodgings and had to watch more than half of our deep dish go to waste. But it was worth it. Pequod's Deep Dish was the most amazing piece of pizza I have ever witnessed and I will sin a hundred times to eat that forbidden pie again. We left Pequod's with our bellies full of pizza and a night full of memories. The decision to go with extra cheese - against the better judgment of our appetite, diet, and/or health - was the right decision. Years from now, Kent24 and I will be throwing back some Coors Light (Kent went to Colorado ONCE) and we will remember this night in Chicago. We will reminisce about Wrigley, we will laugh about the LC, and we will talk about how we once saw a slice of deep dish pizza soared into the cosmos. LITness is forever.SIDE STORYAs many of you may know, Princess Carewee is a plant based homie. Pequod was able to accommodate her with a no-cheese deep dish. The crust was egg-free - we asked. It looked earthly compared to our pie, but she loved it. So yeah, vegan friendly!
Best deep dish in Chicago. Also the veggie pizza have jalapenos that aren't pickled - can get super hot.

Look, we Chicagoans know we have some of the best pizza in the world, right here in our city. But those darned tourists always go to the places advertised in airplane magazines or thise crap places found in search engines. You can be an idiot,  or have the best pizza in Chicago.  Piquads is and should be thought of as top 5! This order as you like it place is all about fresh real ingredients. So your pizza is authentic great tasting food. Their sausage cannot be rivaled. The crust is authentic Italian and has a flavor that enhances the sauces.  There is no best ingredients to their pizzas. I thing veggie pizza is usually a waste but their spices and veggies rule.

It's quite a common thing for a business to, in one fashion or another, claim to be the best. Best in the city, best in the world, best in show; the claim has all but lost its meaning- with one exception: the customers. You can read reviews, take into consideration the opinions of critics, etc. But when you get down what really counts and matters, it's the opinion of the paying customer that matters. And when you hear "best" being used to describe a place over and over by multiple customers, it's best to pay attention.For weeks before visiting Chicago, we had been told by ex-pats and friends alike, that the place to get the best pan pizza in all of Chicago, was Pequad's.And you know what? It really is.Without exaggeration or embellishment, Pequod's is the gold standard of deep dish pizza in all of Chicago (maybe the whole world, for that matter). The crust is thick, crisp, and not doughy or undercooked. The cheese edge is perfectly caramelized, without being burnt. The toppings are thick and  plenty, no matter how many or few you choose. On average, one person can usually eat one, or two slices. So come as a group, or plan on bringing home leftovers (re-heat in a pan or iron skillet, if you do).Now, there are a couple of downsides, that everyone should be aware of, before going in. For starters, on busy days/nights (especially in game nights), and seating is first come-first served, with a long waiting time (don't worry- it's worth it). So, if you can, request a table at least twenty four hours in advance.The other thing to keep in mind, is when it's slammed, your order may be a bit heavy on the sauce. So, when ordering, be sure to ask to go easy on the marinara. Make no mistake about it, Pequad's stands alone. They're incomparable to any other place. They are well worth going out of your way for. I can not recommend them enough. What they serve does not just feed the body, but the soul. But don't take my word for it, try them yourself. You can thank me later.

When in Chicago, we had to try deep dish.  After reading reviews on Yelp and other websites and talking with a few people - we decided to try deep dish here for spot that we served a less touristy deep dish than you'd get near the Loop. The place is sort off the beaten path and the L train and is an old school dive bar with dark lightening so wasn't sure what to expect. We were seated right away and saw the sign to expect a 40 minute wait for pizza but it was sort of an odd time (5pm on a Monday) as we were expecting a much longer wait. We ordered some beers and mozzarella sticks and settled in to await the pizza. Not a ton of other options besides pizza and bar food FYI. Yes, it met the hype! The crust was doughy with a nice sweet tomato sauce and not a ton of cheese, it was thick and delicious especially the caramelized crust. I was stuffed after eating my first slice of small pizza but had to eat the second slice.  With so many reviews, I guess the secret is out where to grab food Chicago deep dish!

You know what's amazing going to a place that doesn't change a damn thing and is still a hit. From living in Chicago 22 years then moving to the burbs to start a family I just had to bring them here. Granted we brought our 10 month old (he's loud but not bitchy) here last night great idea because there was seating up stairs which is the best spot. Nice relaxing still has TVs. Pizza is amazing the sauce is the best in the city the crust and dough is complex yet fluffy. If you crave pizza with a layer of toppings stop by grab a pitcher and relax.
Amazing deep dish. My Chicago friend took me here as they say it's better than the normal touristy deep dish places. So worth the long wait and I can't wait to come back again.

This was my first place I've ever had Chicago style deep dish pizza and it was amazing. I would recommend everyone to come and try this place. It's custom made so you can add whatever you want but just know it does take about atleast 45min for any style of pizza. The service here was great everyone was very friendly. Definitely will be back when I'm in town.

I came here during lunch time in the middle of the week and  the restaurant had a decent amount of people inside. Our server was quick to take drink orders and make ask if we had any questions about the menu. I ended up getting the lunch special which is a personal cheese pizza and a drink for 5 bucks. This is an amazing deal for quality pizza. They said it could take 45 minutes for the pizza to cook but it only ended up being like 25-30 minutes. The pizza itself has nice and crispy crust with a good sauce and plenty of cheese. I had heard a lot about Pequod's and I wasn't disappointed. Next time I'm back in town I would definitely come back and try some of their other pizzas.

Since moving to the Windy City I been looking for the deep dish of all deep dishes. We got here and had giordarnos pizza. It was alright but nothing to write home about. Next we tried Lou Malnati's deep dish pizza. That hit the spot but I felt like it there was something else out there for me to try. After searching high and low, I saw other yelp reviews that Pequod's was the spot to go. After exploring downtown we decided to dabble in this pizza. Boy oh boy I'm so glad we did! The pizza was fire! But the crust stole the show! That crispy burnt cheese was it for me! We ordered the sausage and pepperoni pizza with garlic. Parking sucks around the area and there will be a wait, especially after a Cubs game. I won't dock them a star for that. Too bad I live far as hell to eat this pizza because if I lived close, I would eat this every day! I will be back if I'm in the area!

If you're looking for authentic deep dish pizza, look no further! Got a tip from a local to skip Lou's and Giordano's and get pizza from Pequod's! Indeed they were right. Out of curiosity we tried Lou's and it was awful, I would not recommended it to anyone. Pequod's was the real deal! We got a medium pan pizza with cheese with extra sauce and at first bite, we knew that we were in Chicago! Buttery crust, just the right amount of cheese, and flavorful, homemade sauce.We were staying on N. Michigan Avenue and we realized Pequod's was about 4 miles away so we called and they said they delivered to where we were staying. The girl on the phone was extremely helpful. She told us to order 1 hr and 20 minutes in advance to take into account the cook and delivery time. When the pizza arrived, it was still hot! For a small delivery fee, this was such a better option than taking an Uber there and back.

Everyone has told me that Pequod's does a great deep dish pizza. When I mentioned I was going to Chicago, Chicagoans unanimously said I had to stop by Pequod's. I'm definitely glad I went, and I had a good time, but I guess deep dish just isn't my thing. Here goes the review:We stopped by Pequod's in the late afternoon on a Friday. We were prepared to wait, but got lucky and were seated right away. We were informed that the wait for pizza would be ~45 minutes; I think it ended up being a little less. We went for the medium deep dish with spinach and sausages. The pizza is so bread-y (in the words of my friend, it felt like "90% bread") that though the pizza didn't look large, it was massively filling. The fillings were generous (so much cheese, so much sauce, basically an entire layer of spinach and copious amounts of sausage) and very liquid-y, but the crust held up well to all that moisture. That being said, it was a fork-and-knife pizza experience.Our favorite part of the pizza was the sausage, which had a prominent fennel flavor and a juicy bite. The cheese had that good stretchy pull, but was on the bland side, and we needed a good sprinkle of red pepper flakes to add some flavor. And I know that deep dishes are about that thick crust, but there was so. much. bread.Service was about what you'd expect for a busy, pub-style sort of place - they took our order in a timely manner, but it was difficult to flag down staff for water refills and red pepper flakes (which should be available at all tables). Prices were fair; we each paid ~$11, including tip. I'm glad we stopped by and experienced deep dish, and I can appreciate that there's something comforting about a pan filled with bread, tomato sauce, assorted toppings, and melted cheese. But ultimately, Pequod's didn't win me over, and as far as deep dish goes, I don't have any burning desire to eat it again any time soon.

Visited this place for lunch around 3pm on a Saturday. Although the sign showed that their was a 45 min wait for the pizza, ours arrived in 25 min which was nice.We ordered house salad which was totally average. Only ordered it to get some nutrients. We shared a personal pan pizza (which is the smallest size) given we had a heavy breakfast. Our toppings included onions, garlic, mushrooms and black olives. Overall the pizza was good and very filling. But thought it wasn't the best pizza we had in Chicago.Overall worth trying if the waiting time is less than 45 min.

2 yrs is not enough to get to know all the deliciousness Chicago has to offer unless you're lucky enough to have experienced company around you. That is basically how I came across Pequod's. I'm personally not a crazy, salivating at the thought of a deep dish fan and have only had my occasional Giordanos or Lou's. So, when I was told how awesome this joint is I was honestly not expecting a lot. However, when I got to try their risky, on the edge, slightly burnt buttery crust topped with the amazing lava of sauce and veggies- It was quite a surprise. We had ordered on phone before heading to Pequod's so the service was fairly quick. Once seated, the ambience was very casual, like a neighborhood bar- food joint.  Servers were sweet, guided us well and refilled our drinks on time. I've heard this place gets crazy packed on weekends and rush hours so call beforehand. We got lucky with the parking but it's usually on a busy street. Overall very pleased, will return and will recommend to all my tourist friends in search of that good ol' deep dish.

Personally, the best pizza in Chicago. Not, perhaps a "real" deep dish... but in a pan, with caramelized, delicious crusts, nice layer of cheese (if you're expecting a lot of cheese like on other deep dish pizzas filled half with tomato sauce and half with cheese, you should ask for an extra topping of cheese) and filled with fresh, yummy ingredients. While searching for deep dish, I've been to the famed Lou Malnati's  and Giordanos but was never wowed. I thought it was just that I don't really like deep dish. It is too big, too soggy, too salty and too tomatoyee. Well, wether Pequod's is real deep dish or its fixed version, this is one pizza I like! It's definitely not NY style thin or Costco pizza (which I like, btw, but I wouldn't say they are better than Pequod's as some reviewer mentioned... at least personally, this here is definitely worth it), and also crusty and filled with yummy ingredients. I like that the tomato sauce is not overpowering. On this last visit, I thought they had skimped out on cheese though. The last several times I've been, the cheese was oozing out while the server was serving up the pizza, but this time, it definitely stayed in place, and I could taste it less. I hope it was just a temporary hiccup rather than a permanent cost saving tactic. Their $4.95 lunch specials come with a personal size pizza and a drink. Some years ago, it was with a beer but that's changed to a fountain drink. I really like this personal size... Feels like more caramelized deliciousness. We ordered a large pizza with pepperoni, mushrooms, onions and garlic, and they definitely loaded it up. We also shared the app combo. Glad we did, since we were hungry and the pizza takes 40 minutes to cook. Yes, either order ahead (I'm not sure you can, actually, but I should next time I go), or be ready to wait. The appetizer combo came with 4 pieces of each item so the 4 of us in our party didn't have to fight over anything. So sorry Lou, sorry Giordano... Pequod's is where I go!

Love their deep dish here! Also love their personal sized pizza lunch special. I've tried one other deep dish pizza in Chicago, and I must say I love Pequod's much more.The pizza will take a little while to bake, but the crunchy crust and crisp cheese edge is worth it! Also not too bready and packed with flavor.

I love Pequod's! Some of the best deep dish pizza in the city. I think the crust is perfect. I like the deep dish with mushrooms and spinach. I also have had the pesto pasta and the pequods salad which is so good. It is totally worth the wait! But if you do not want to wait then I would recommend going at an off time. Definitely a great place to take out of town guests or people that really love pizza!!!
Super crunchy crust Better to add giardiniera for a little spice. :) The wait is about 30 mins. But worth it.

The reviews don't lie. The pizza is fantastic. The crust is crispy, charred in some places, thick and substantial. Toppings are generous and large size - meaning when we ordered green peppers, they were thick slices. When we ordered Italian sausage, it was big flavorful pieces. Wait time is what it is. Pequod's is simply too popular to keep the crowds away. Call in your order ahead of time and when you arrive and are seated, then the original 40 minute cooking time will be reduced to 20 minutes. Appetizers are small in my opinion. We had the zucchini slices and it was barely enough for 4 people. Everyone has a favorite pizza joint. This is mine. And I've come from out of town twice to eat here because it's THAT good. If you're a major cheese lover, Pequod's won't be for you because their specialty is the crust. They don't drown their pizzas in cheese.

Best deep dish pizza in Chicago, on par with Giordano's in my opinion.  The front of the building is small, and upon stepping inside I thought the space was tiny.  But there is a second floor and it telescopes back, plenty of room, but show up earlier than later to have a shorter wait time.The pan pizza will take ~45 min to cook, so start with some drinks and appetizers.  The garlic bread and marinara sauce was large, but not especially flavorful, get it if you want but also try other things on the menu.  The pizza itself is why everyone comes to Pequod's and it meets the hype.  The crust on the pan pizza is caramelized in a way that Lou's tries, but Pequod's expertly accomplishes.  The crust adds an extra dimension to the pizza that Lou's or Giordano's cannot match.  The crust is thicker at Pequod's than other places, but the topping to crust ratio is appropriate. The ingredients on the pizza are also top notch, the sausage was flavorful and the basil aromatic after cooking.  The waiters do serve the pizza for you, and do so aggressively so I didn't get a photo of the whole pizza.

Pequod's is hands down my favorite deep dish pizza. I would not recommend the thin crust. I love the burnt cheese on the edges. I get extra cheese because I'm a cheese lover and they don't use as much as I'm accustomed to on a deep dish pizza.

We came to Pequod's after I ran the Wisconsin marathon, and it was probably the best decision we could've made. We got a medium pizza with sausage and pepperoni-- the sausage chunks were huge and they loaded the pizza with pepperoni slices. I ate half and my boyfriend ate the other half, and we were stuffed. Everything about this pizza was perfect! I also loved the atmosphere of this restaurant. It seemed like the perfect college town pizza place. Tons of seating also, we were expecting to have to wait when we first entered but we very quickly got seated on the second floor. Good selection of beer on draft, small selection of wine; we asked about a cocktail menu but they only have the basic liquors and no menu. Not a problem to me, beer goes perfectly with beer!

I took your advice.  I took all of your advice on my first trip to Chicago, and I'm so glad I did.  I only had the time (and the desire, tbh) for one deep dish pizza while in the city, and I went with Pequod's.  And it was absolutely phenomenal.  The personal pizza with pepperoni added is the way to go, do not second guess yourself.  And the staff was so friendly!  I took a Lyft straight from the airport here, and they didn't make me feel silly at all when I rolled my suitcase through the door like the goofy tourist I was.  Best pizza, best pizza joint.
I used to come here way back in the day. It's typical Chicago style deep dish and it's delicious. I'm a big Lou Malnatis fan but this comes pretty close.

Super dive bar-y style pizza joint. With both an upstairs and a downstairs, it was much larger than I anticipated, and insanely crowded. I appreciated that they did an amazing job helping us to party plan. Everything from taking our 20 person reservation to discussing bill breakdown to pre-ordering was above and beyond. Our service was attentive throughout and everything came out quickly and promptly (trust me when I say order ahead, or you'll be hangry waiting 60 minutes for your pizza!). Personal pizza preference for me is the thinner the crust, the better, and their thin crust did not disappoint! Don't fret if you're not a fan of deep dish because this is a great option. Their pan style pizza crust was also delicious; "burnt" and crispy, which is just my style. So happy I finally got to experience this Chicago classic! :)

Pequod's!!! WTF have I been doing as a Chicagoan that it took me this long to try you?! I'm not going to lie, I've always been a Lou's loyalist when it comes to Chi Pizza - but y'all are giving them a serious run for their money. First things first, I get this isn't deep dish in our traditional sense, but it dang sure ain't thin crust. It is its own style 'Pan Pizza' as they call it, with a lot of crust and less cheese to it.I think I always overlooked Pequod's since it's a bit more humble in it's building (a two story spot in Lincoln Park with another location in Morton Grove) and also not having a million locations like some of the other pizza chains. Let me advise everyone else, don't follow in my footsteps! Do ~not~ sleep on Pequod's!I tried the Sausage Pizza last night and as mentioned, it has a crispy crust thicker than you're used to while still a bit airy, less cheese, less sauce and a decent amount of sausage on top. It was everything I dreamed it could be - tasty from the first bite to the last. I am a weak sauce and could only shovel one piece down the hatch (and I even struggled with the one piece) but others in my group had 2, even 3 pieces so YMMV. If you go to their actual location, you'll get the pie piping hot & fresh from the oven! But don't front, you may just want to take it to go to eat in shame alone while Netflixing and there's nothing wrong with that. Just be sure to dig in as soon as you can to get all the warm goodness you deserve.I saw online they do a 'Chicago Lunch Special' - $4.95 for a 7" pan cheese pizza with a drink, Monday-Friday 11am-3pm for dine in orders. Yep, I'll be back for that.

Best Chicago deep dish pizza I've had, I think I see where some of the criticisms come into play, particularly involving the sauce/dough ratio, but there's something just good about having that doughyness. The best part is definitely the charred cheesy crust, its really to die for. If you come at the right time the wait could actually be zero, aka a Thursday afternoon. Overall loved my experience there

The best deep dish in Chicago, and I've had them all. As a stuck up former New Yorker, I take my pizza seriously. Pequod's delivers with that unique carmelized crust, and a lightness to their pies that others lack. Cool vibe, but be prepared to wait.

Pequods pizza does deep dish well. They have this 4.95 deal on the weekdays for the regular cheese pizza. You can add toppings at the price of 80cents each. Totally worth it to try it on the weekdays. I heard that on the weekend the wait can go over 3 hrs. So be prepared to wait. We got seated right away during lunch and pizza takes around 40 minutes to make. So do get some appetizers and their CHILI. Omg so gooooood. Deep dish pizza is doughy... and I can't really finish it but I can say I tried it! From LA to Chicago.

I've lived in Chicago (suburbs) most of my life, and prior to this I lived in Connecticut... I know the pizza game. First and foremost you HAVE to understand deep dish and ny-style are fundamentally different foods. Think of it like comparing vodka to beer... Sure they're both alcohol but everybody has a PREFERENCE.That said, wherever you sit on the Lou's/Gio's debate, I feel comfortable and confident saying this place is the best in all of Chicago. The carmelized crust brings this pizza to the next level. If you're from out of town and want to do things "the Chicago way" I reccomend getting your pizza with green peppers, mushrooms and sausage. In terms of portion sizes, normal eaters can usually eat 1-1.5 slices of the 12", and big eaters maybe 2-3, absolutely no more.The place is pretty big (upstairs / downstairs) but I'd reccomend budgeting about 2.5 hours all said-and-done if you come on a Friday night or Saturday night. Wait times can  exceed an hour, then it takes about 45-60 minutes to get your pizza after getting seated. I went once on a Saturday afternoon and we were seated right away. I believe you can also phone in advance to get "priority seating" (not a reservation) which is probably worthwhile if you're going at a peak time.I reccomend ordering as soon as you sit down. While you wait, you can order drinks (they're pretty inexpensive) or apps. The apps are very average- avoid the bread but the mozz sticks were solid. The service definitely isn't stellar here, but the pizza MORE than makes up for it, as do the very low prices, realative to the big dd chains. You could easily come out with a tab under $50 for 4 people.This is unequivocally the best dd spot in all of Chicago and I always have (and will continue) to bring all of my nyc / west coast friends here when they visit.

My first time here: 2 large pizzas was just perfect for 8 of us (I was a bit stuffed though). We were lucky to be able to grab a reservation since there was a large group of us. Pizza was good, they didn't skimp on toppings at all. Service was good as well. Ended up being $16pp which is very reasonable since everyone had a drink. Only complaint is that it's pretty crampy (one could say cozy) and loud, and I wasn't a fan of the restrooms.
Amazing pizza! Best I've ever had! Thanks to my uber driver David for the recommendation!

Pequod's is one of my husband's favorite places for pizza. Unfortunately, its a little further away from our house so its a special trip every time we go here. The pizza is no doubt really good whether it'd be deep dish or pan pizza. I am not personally a fan of their pasta but I do like their pan pizza. We've been here for dinner with our friends and on birthdays and certainly turned out to be great. I would recommend this place to anyone whether a visitor (we've done this plenty of times) or chicagoan (if they haven't already been here).
This ranks in my top 3 list for thin crust Pizza.  Great crust, sauce, sausage, pepperoni, mushroom & onion absolutely fantastic!

First visit on a Friday night and this place is packed!  A friend arrived around 6:30 to put our names in, we were seated an hour later, with pizza(s)* arriving a bit less than an hour after that.  Issue with a super burnt crust first pizza (which I'm told is rare as others in my group have been multiple times attest), but service was quick and accommodating for our surprise +2 guests and high chair, and discounted our total bill for the problem.*Second pizza was delayed as they messed up the order, so was brought out later.  We crunched through the first burnt pizza (we think they left it on too long to wait for the second originally and that caused the burntness).And of course - the main thing to review: the pizza is amazing and totally worth the raves. The second was done to perfection, and even the first burnt one was delicious when creating the top off the crust bottom.  My friends were disappointed, but I don't care much for the bread anyways ao or was not a big deal to me. In any case, the way Pequad's does toppings is excellent. Overall:  Service 5Atmosphere 4.5Food 4.5Highly recommend ordering carry out, since the wait takes a while (2 hours before food, unless you order appetizer) and the place can be a bit claustrophobic for some with the crowds.

In any other city, Pequod's would likely be standout 'pan' (i.e. deep dish) pizza.. But in Chicago, it unfortunately falls to the middle of the pack:1) Lou Malnati's 2) Pizzeria Uno 3) PEQUOD's4) Gino's East5) Giordano'sThe toppings were plentiful and the sauce was well balanced - nothing ruins a good slice of deep dish like drowning it in tomato sauce. The caramelized crust is an especially nice touch.The one major downfall of Pequod's is their crust-to-cheese ratio.. Although the crust is light and airy - and significantly better tasting than most crust-heavy options - each slice is mostly dough with a thin layer of cheese and toppings. Double the cheese, half the crust.. & you have a winning combination.Pequod's is worth the visit, but be prepared to wait.. Getting a table at peak times can take an hour or more, and ordering a pan will set you back another 45 min. Get there early.. Take your time. Enjoy a slice.. Or simply order ahead for instant gratification.

I have spent a lot A LOT of time in Chicago. I took a recommendation from people who live locally and Pequod's is BY FAR the best Chicago deep dish. Anyone who tells you different hasn't branched our or they are a tourist. The pizza came out at a great pace and we started off with beers and some side salads. The service was prompt and attentive. Love it. I'll keep coming here for sure and I highly recommend you check it out. The pizza is very filling. The picture is of a small. For two people we had half left and were very full. Pro tip: coming in during off hours so you don't have to wait. The wait can be incredibly long during dinner hours!

Pequod's is my hand's down choice for best pizza in Chicago. I have nothing new to say that 2000 other reviewers haven't. This is the type of place that causes traffic jams from all the people trying to dine in and take-out and blocking the lane next to the traffic light. Pequods is deceptively large, with two expansive floors and hundreds of tables, yet the wait is never less than 30 minutes. It's that good.Anyone who tells you they didn't love Pequods, ask them if they had it at the restaurant or as take out. The take out is good, but this pizza was MEANT to be eaten fresh out of the oven and it is world's better when eaten as dine-in. The crunchy chewy bite of the burnt cheese crust adds such a depth of flavor to each slice. Save Lou Malnattis, Gino's, Giordannos for the tourists, eat like a local and get Pequods.Pro-tip: Grab a beer at their sister bar next door while you wait, and check out the fried zucchini flowers appetizer.

Still the reigning champ. Came back here and got a small, half cheese / half pepperoni, which was perfect for two people. (Two slices each, which left me full, but not disgusting.)Absolutely the best deep dish I've ever had, and a staple of my Chicago trips.

Now on to the Pizza BEST eats spots.  We tried three spots on our trip.Pequod's takes the pie, hahaha!  Pizza is so so delicious, you never want to stop eating.Awesome place, with upstairs seating in addition to the main seating, always busy.  Both visits we were able to grab seats at the bar and avoid the wait lines.Ordered the small pizza on the first visit, plenty for two, and the personal on day 2, a second lunch...we were crazy, but that is how good this place.Go and judge for yourself!

Pequod's isn't exactly the deep dish one would expect, but it definitely has a following that's greater than any traditional deep-dish spot. A deep doughy pizza with baked cheese on the outside, making the crust look burnt. However, the crunch really sets it apart from many competitors. Pure Perfection!

I've lived in Chicago for about 4 years now and never been a huge fan of Chicago style deep dish pizza. But my experience at Pequod's makes me now think that I'm just not a fan of Giordano's and Malnati's, not Chicago pizza as a whole, because Pequod's was and is THE PIZZA OF MY LIFE. It's also a huge plus they're open late!

I love my trips to Chicago mostly for the pizza.  A colleague insisted we go to Pequod's as it was supposed to be better than Lou's.  Perhaps "better" is dependent on individual taste.    I ordered a caesar with anchovies and was not disappointment except for the small portion of dressing.    We split a small pizza with sausage, bell peppers and mushrooms.   The crust, cheese and sauce were as good as advertised but the sausage and bell peppers were overpowering and left me slightly disappointed.   I enjoyed the sausage by itself, as most of it falls off anyway.  And maybe I'm just not a fresh bell pepper lover.  If you go to Chicago, it is worth a stop but you might start with something like just cheese and pepperoni.

This off the beaten path deep dish pizza place came highly recommended. I was told to stay away from the chain deep dish and try this one. It is a little place near Lincoln Park. It is known for long waits and great pizza. We arrived early At about 4:30 PM expecting a long wait and we were seated immediately. We got their house special salad and put in our order for a large deep dish with pepperoni, sausage, and onion. The salad was very good and when the pizza came I was amazed. It was not too greasy but it did have a lot of sauce. I thought it was some of the best deep dish I had ever tried and was very glad I did not go to one of the chains. The place does not have a lot of personality but it is all business when it comes to their pizza.  Service was good and prices were very reasonable it was 1875 for large pie and three dollars for each additional item.

This review could be a little biased since I haven't had Chicago pizza up until this point. I moved from Cleveland this week and picked the place with the highest number of reviews above 3 1/2 stars. Let me tell you, this pizza is a different experience. Sorry in advance for this next comment Chicago, but this is my outside view of what I thought your pizza would be like.... I thought Chicago pizza would be a giant bread bowl with tomato soup. Haha  It's DEFINITELY not! This was a first time pizza experience and it was unlike anything I've had before. The crust is what makes it so good. It looks burnt, but it's not it's caramelized stick to your ribs crust. If you're looking for the ultimate comfort food look no further.

Finally, I've been here a second time. And I don't know what it is, but I'm not head over heels about this place like some people are.Don't get me wrong, I've got a lot of respect for the caramelized crust, which is a nice little take on deep dish (which, to be honest, can only be modified so much). But I still like Lou Malnati's crust more.Obviously this place has a better, divey vibe, which I like.

I love stopping here whenever I'm in Chicago. My first visit was sometime at the end of May in 2017, and I loved it. I don't travel that often, and I thought I would never get to eat here again. But then I found myself in Chicago on September 2, and made a point to stop here.When I arrived, there were people waiting outside for tables. I realized that things were probably not going to work out for me with regard to getting a table. When I stepped inside there was barely any room to move, because so many people were waiting either to get to the host stand, or to order food to go or to pick up their to go orders.I got to the host stand and I was told that there was an hour and a half wait. I asked if I could place an order to go, and the host indicated that I could but that was a separate line. I got in that line and when I got to the front the woman with whom I was speaking indicated that there was a place at the bar and that I could sit there if I would like. So I did.When I sat at the bar, the bartender/waitress indicated that there was an hour and a half wait. I've already been told this by the host I had already accepted it. I placed my order and then sat and waited. About an hour and 15 minutes later my food came to me. It was hot and delicious. Deep dish pizza with pepperoni, green olives, and pineapple. Suck it if you don't like it. I love pineapple on pizza.When I was about finished eating, a woman who had come in about 30 minutes after I did, and who was also sitting at the bar, said to the bartender "I'm a food blogger, and I was hoping to give you a good rating but having to wait an hour and 15 minutes for a personal size pizza is bullsh*t." The bartender apologized. And then a few minutes later gave the woman an update and told her that her food was coming out soon.
