PEQUOD'S HAS THE BEST CHICAGO-STYLE PIZZA IN CHICAGO AND I WILL FIGHT YOU IF YOU DISAGREEPepperoni + onion + green pepper is the go-to.  Keep it simple, stupid.Side note: their Italian salad dressing is da bomb.  I'm sure it's from a bottle or whatever but screw you, I would drink that shit.Pro-tip: go to the Drinkingbird next door afterwards for some good (and cheap) after-dinner craft cocktails
Best pizza ever!  The cast iron pan it is baked in makes all the difference in the world!  Never disappoints

This Pizzeria is on my top 3 places to get a slice of pizzzza! I still haven't many places that I need to check out but this place is the one place I like to take girls out to dinner who are pizza lovers. I do recommend it to some folks also, because, well its delicious lolAnyways, the best part for me is that the crust looks burn but its actually especially delicious

Nothing like it in the city!  Delicious :)  I usually get pineapple as an extra, and it never disappoints.  You won't break the bank here, either. It's a special treat for a pick up to bring home, too.

A true Chicago institution, been going to Pequod's since late 90's and they have never disappointed. Simply delicious pizza and good value. Great vibe, always look forward to a slice whenever I am in the neighborhood.

My fellow New Yorkers know - Chicago deep-dish pizza ain't pizza. The dense vessel of bread augmented with a vertical growth of irrelevant toppings and something like an inch of cheese is more like pie, or bad lasagna... or some other obscene thing characterized by gross excessiveness rather than a relationship to that majestic food form we call pizza.That said, Pequod's serves up a damn delicious deep dish "pizza" (yes, you still need a fork to eat it).The difference between Pequod's and the other, very overrated Chicago deep-dish heavyweights is that Pequod's lines the cast-iron pan with cheese before baking the pizza. The result is a beautifully blackened edge of, yep, fried cheese - that holds the pizza together instead of becoming soggy after a minute and breaking off from the rest of the pie. The crust is also slightly thinner than the refined carb parties of Lou Malnati's or Giordano's, both of whom have totally mediocre deep-dish due to a dry monster crust of solid bread and an avalanche of cheese and too-sweet sauce that slides off the second you lift your slice out of the pan.Our medium "pan pizza" (as they call it) with jalapenos and mushrooms cost $20 and was ready for pickup in 30 minutes. The restaurant looks like a regular old Chicago bar: low-key, dirty worn wooden floors, maybe you'd see lots of daisy dukes if it had been warm enough. It was totally empty on a Wednesday at 10:30pm, though they're open conveniently til 2am. Call ahead to place an order even if eating in, since the pizza takes a half hour to cook either way.The first deep dish I've actually liked as food and not spectacle! Mmm.
The best deep dish, hands down!I have tried Giardinos, Gino's, and Lou Malnati's and this is my personal favorite.Be prepared to wait, as this place is very popular.

I work in the area and I always see the lines of people waiting. My boyfriend and I decided to check this place out on a Saturday, we didn't have to wait and were seated right away. Staff was friendly, attentive and awesome. The pizza was to die for!!!! We found our new favorite pizza place.

Hmmm delicious... the crunchy cheese on the edge of the crust is so good. It is a bit outside of the more common and touristy areas and I am glad we ventured out here. Had Lou Malnati's last time, which I very much enjoyed, but I think Pequod's is even better. Lunch special is a really good deal too!
My fav deep dish pizza in Chicago. Less hassle than the others in terms of getting a seat. Their crust is the best. Always reliable
Loved the deep dish pizza with its caramelised crust.. Sauce is really good. Would definitely recommend!Service could be more attentive though.

Every time I come here, I have to get their pan pizza (they say it's deep dish, but I don't really consider it deep dish?). Anyway, their pizza is amaaaaaaaaaaaazing. Their ingredients are so fresh and I LOVE the crust (and I NEVER eat pizza crust). Good beer on tap, and the server checks in regularly. :)

Very chill place to go and sit down, get a pitcher  beer, and a pizza and you will be the happiest person ever. I've also gotten delivery and never been let down.Thin crust is solid, but if you are venturing Pequods, get the deep dish. It is possibly the greatest in the city of Chicago, right up there with lou's and art of pizza. The caramelized crust is something to tell your mother about (i know i told her bout it last night).

By far the best pizza in Chicago. The cast iron baked pan crust is so ridiculously good I have dreams about it. The place does get really busy during popular hours and the service starts to slow, but the pizza is well worth the wait. Definitely a must try if you haven't already.

This was my 2nd time dining in. Service was great staff is very polite. It was my surprise for my Hubby. It was our 10year anniversary. I was able to enjoy the thin crust pizza. They said it would be able 45 minute to wait on the pizza to come out. They served us in 20 minutes. We were pleased.

Its a bit of a throw down with Chicago deep dish between Pequods and Lou's Personally we feel that Pequods has tastier and more plentiful toppings. As some folks may have seen in our other posts we are into thin crust better. However when we get the chance we certainly try to frequent Pequods.
Best deep dish in Chicago! Once you order it's a bit of a wait to receive your food but it's definitely worth it! They make their pizza fresh and cook the crust to the perfect level of crisp.
Awesome pizza! Ordered a large sausage and pepperoni pie. Huge for two people. The beer on draft is really good. Definitely coming back next time I'm in Chicago!
Meh.  The pizza was good but not exceptional. I know this pizzeria is popular -- place was hopping on a weekday afternoon -- but for both atmosphere and pizza, it rates a B- in my book.
Hands down my favorite pizza in Chicago. It's a pan pizza with the mozzarella caramelized on the outside to form a crust. The pepperoni is good and crispy at the edges.

Heard many reviews and comments about this place and with chicago having many pizza places i figured i needed to compare lou's.... soo that being said i think this place was amazing, not a long wait at all and definitely go again. Galric cheest bread was amazing and the atmosphere was pretty cool but busy.

The pizza here is excellent. It's as good as Lou Malnati's just different. We waited a very long time to get in. By the time the pizza came we were starving even though we ordered an appetizer and a salad. I wish it wasn't such a long wait. I understand that pizza takes time to cook.

The pizza is still rockstar and continues to be.  Can't tell you how many tourists I've brought here over the years and they've been wow'ed.  The pan pizza is that effing awesome.  It is.  If Pequod's & Yelp sold marketing information about Yelpers to doctors, I'd be screwed.  I think the most times I've been to this location in one year would be over thirty for sure.  When entertaining guests that bitch and moan about a Chicago pie, if you must bring them here, the reacharound is to get a thin crust for them.  It's not bad, it's middle ground.  Personally I never order it.  Thin crust is also available by the slice.For all the naysayers that say "what's the deal, why the long wait for blah blah blah" Go to Pizza hut, there's no wait there.  For realz.Two awesome details about Pequod's.  They are open till 2 am six days a week and midnight on Sunday.  So there are plenty of times you can get in here and get a pie.  After the bars or a late night of happy hours, its a great way to end a good evening.  Second detail, their lunch special.  They've offered it forever.  Personal pan with one  topping and a soda or beer for $4.95.  That is a deal that cannot be beaten at any pizza joint, it's perfect.  At times when I'm dining with people with too many topping requests, I'll order an individual and I'll be content.  I think a Pequod's pie is best with minimal toppings, three max depending on what's ordered.Service wise.. it's not that it's hit or miss.  Just depends on the night.  I think the waitresses can be overworked because it gets hella busy.  There's the main floor and then there is also a second floor for much more seating.  I keep hearing about a beer garden but I've never seen it or forget to ask.  As a norm I always place my pizza order ahead of time.  It's almost ready to be served when I arrive and it's piping hot.I know once a few friends see this review I may get a text to join for some awesome Za over the weekend.  If you use a smart phone and "check in" to places, you can often see a popup mentioning other Yelp users being here as well.  At least in my experiences.

I just don't really understand why people think this is the best pizza in the city. It's good, but not oh my gawwd so ahmazingg good, that I wouldn't go anywhere else.  Always expect to wait a long time to get in.

I've never had legitimate Chicago deep dish until this past weekend. Also, I've never been to Lou Malnati's so I can't compare the two. I just know that Pequod's was really, REALLY good.We had reservations at 6:30pm. Their version of "reservations" is basically priority seating, you still have to wait a bit depending on how many people are there. I'd recommend waiting outside (if it's not too chilly) because it's quite crowded inside around dinner time and you can get bonked on the head or jabbed in the back with some pizza pans. Also while you're waiting, you can start looking at the menu and deciding what you want. You can even order before you sit down! Something I wish we had known..We sat down and ordered a pitcher of Goose Island 312. Great local beer, btw. The three of us also ordered cheesy garlic bread for starters. We were reluctant since we knew there would be a lot of carbs to be consumed with our deep dish, but went for it anyways. It was one of the best decisions ever.A common mistake that people make is forgetting this is deep dish. Usually it would be perfectly fine for 3 people to get a large 14" NY style pizza, but since this was Chicago style, we downsized to a medium 10" (sausage, mushroom, onion) and still struggled to finish. There were 6 slices and we all struggled finishing the last one. I think I left half of it on my plate and ended up picking at the toppings because I could not physically fit any more food in my stomach. I wanted to though. It was sooooo good, the crust and bottom were buttery and crispy, the middle was soft and doughy. There was just enough sauce and a good amount of toppings. I couldn't ask for a better first deep dish experience!
Hands down best deep dish in Chicago. Don't bother eating there because you will wait forever. Takeout is a must. Once you've had this you won't go back for any other deep dish. That is all.

Pequods pizza is on my top 3 list for deep dish in Chicago. The only thing keeping it from 5 stars to me is the typical wait for a table as well as pizza, which for me has ranged from 1.5-2.5 hours. Understandably deep dish pizza takes a while to make but this is longer than other places I have been.The pizza itself is stupendous and the garlic bread for an appetizer is bomb!

Another SERIOUSLY good pizza place in chicago.  Im getting fatter as i write this review.  Jeez  i cant say enough good stuff   SLOW delivery   but i mean.... genious pizza takes time to create.  IM OBSESSED    thank you for being a friend Pequod's Pizza

The question I imagine everyone asks is 'How does the deep dish compare to the other establishments?'Really well, I'm not a deep dish connoisseur, but of the ones I've had, this one rates the best. For me it was the crust. It was still crispy and great with all the gooey cheese. Whenever we visit Chicago and are craving deep dish- we'll come here first :)

Pequod's is THE BEST pizza in Chicago. Seriously close off your ears and yell very loudly at anyone who tells you differently, especially if it's your friend from Indiana who wants to go to Uno's or Lou's..... Get new friends.Pizza is like french fries, it's hard to have "a bad pizza" but Pequod's takes it to the next level. The toppings are premium (try their homemade Italian sausage), the sauce delish and oh my: the crust. It's doughy AND crispy. Mind blown.Sure, there are other excellent pizza places in Chicago, and you should try them all. And that folks is why Chicago is awesome.
We come here for birthdays. My kids make sure of that. We're always satsified.

I haven't had Lou Manalti's, but I figured I would give this place a try first because it is harder to get to for me. Disclaimer: I don't usually like deep dish pizza, and if I had a choice, I would go for NY style any day.This deep dish was different than those I had before. There's actually very little tomato sauce and the toppings lie on top (compared to ones I've had before which were filled with a tomato sauce / topping mixture).What I really like is the caramelized cheese edges, so crispy! I also like that despite all the wet toppings on top, the bread on the bottom below the cheese remained completely dry! Not soggy at all! I think that's a huge feat to accomplish. For these two things alone, I give this place 4 stars. Also, the slices are huge! I shared a small pizza ( 4 slices) with one other person, and was pretty satisfied after just 1 slice. I continued to stuff my face, and ate another 1/2 of a slice. Yum!

One of the best pizza places in the city for deep dish or pan pizza. Make sure to bring plenty of friends because, speaking from personal experience, there is no way just two people could eat one of their medium sized pan pizzas. It is usually quite crowded on weekends or game nights so be prepared to wait a bit, but the wait will most definitely be worth it.

Not many places in my opinion should get 5-stars but this place is a staple of mine. Now that I do not live in Chicago ALL deep dish pizza I try are automatically compared to my Pequad's Pizzeria. My go to Pizza toppings include ground beef and spinach or simply a cheese!  Top that off with your favorite drink and get ready to dive in.Be prepared to wait if you are trying to go on a Friday or Saturday night as this place has set a reputation for some of the best pizza in all Chicago. More good can be said but "if you don't know, now you know" - B.I.G
better than Giordanos!!yummy deep dish pizza with caramel crust and we ordered wings as well as raviolli which were equally yummy! :D

As a New Yorker I have a very specific idea of pizza. However, whenever I want deep dish style of "pizza", I go to Chicago to find the best pie. I've had Giordanos and Ginos but I absolutely prefer the way the Pequod's cooks theirs. The crust is dark and caramelized and the whole pie is cooked so well. The sauce is tasty and the base crust is the right crunch. The service is great and the waiters are personable, despite being so busy.

Get deep dish pizza with pepperoni and hot giardinera. This pizza warrants 5+ stars, hands down. Skip the apps, salads, and thin crust altogether. Don't expect much from the service or decor. Just get this pizza in your mouth now!

So far this is the best deepdish I had in town. Everyone talks about the baked cheese on the crust and there's a reason! The cheese on this was very generous, think giordanos, while the ingredients were fresh. What really caught me was the tomato sauce, they do it right. Good amount of tangy sweet. The place itself was dimly lit, and we couldn't find great seats, it was pretty crowded. But deep dish, after here, has become a new thing for me!

Best deep dish in Chicago, no doubt. My only complaint is that the pies can sometimes be a little inconsistent and on occasion the cheese-to-bread ratio gets out of whack. I generally solve that by always ordering extra cheese with my pepperoni pie. The pizza is better when you dine in, no question, but the delivery is still enjoyable as long as you don't let it sit. Reheat in the oven, not in the microwave, natch.
I used to live around the corner and remember the mural! Looking forward to visiting shin when I'm in town! Miss the caramelized cheese on the crust. No one does it like Pequods!

Got a small deep dish with onion, mushroom and spinach! So delicious. Very fresh and it was enough to leave us both very full. Also had the cheesy garlic which was great. Service was awesome and super helpful. Pizza takes a while to come out so I would recommend a heavy drink and/or an app.

I'm not the biggest fan of deep dish pizza however this place seems to pull at my heart strings.  Keep in mind, this is not your normal deep dish.  The caramelized crust is awesome and we always go with the meatball topping.   The sauce tastes similar to homemade red sauce.  You should definitely give this a try.
Sensational. I had PTPD, post traumatic pizza disorder, after Lou Malnati's but tried Pequod's anyway. This is what every pizza wished it could be. Taste it to believe it. Wings are excellent too.

According my friend " the sausage dominates." And he's right and I know there's a million great reviews of this place but it would really be lovely if they had something that was fresh like a salad or even I'll take antipasti something that isn't a pizza but if that's what you're going for go get it cuz that is delish.

As a first timer to Chicago, I had to try the deep dish pizza since it's one of the must have foods if you are a visitor to Chicago.  Deep dish means your crust will be extra thick.  I had it with mushrooms, you can add as many toppings as you want, at a price, I didn't want to overload my pizza and wanted something simple.  The cheese was good and the crust was very tasty.  You can get something small, it will suffice for two people.  I also had the soup of the day, which was tomato bisque, very flavorful.  The waiter explained everything to us and was helpful. The place is more like a sports bar with good food.
The best pizza in Chicago. The crust is mouth watering and pictures do not do it justice. A must eat and will be back soon.
This is hands down my most visited spot for deep dish whenever I have guests in town or just for myself because it's that's good. Don't even think hat other spots could be compared to this one.
The pizza here is just as good as the place in Morton Grove, which is to say maybe the best Chicago style pizza ever.  Still, I like the original location better.  I'm not sure why.

My favorite restaurant and pizza in Chicago - hands down. Way better than Giordano's and Lou Malnati's if you like a more unique flavor and recipe. Yes, it gets crowded, but you can put your name in online a few days in advance and can also grab a drink at the Whale Tale next door while you wait. I never get sick of this place. Would highly recommend getting garlic on your deep dish. Definitely go here!

I'm a fan of the ambiance and the vibe Pequod's gives out - however their pizza was just not for me.  Their crust is very unique and obviously they have a huge following, but it was not my favorite.  I would truly recommend this place though - you have to try it and find out for yourself!! Be prepared for a line or go during an "off-time".

New Yorkers tend to be snobby about pizza in Chicago. We think we have the best pizza, they think they have the best pizza, it's a rivalry through the ages.As a New Yorker used to thinner style pizza, the "deep dish" here was perfect. I've had deep dish elsewhere and it was too crispy (Looking at you Pizanos!)The pizza here is soft and made with amazing ingredients. It's easy to cut and a pleasure to eat. As everyone else said, the caramelized mozzarella on the crust makes the whole slide good to the last bit! I've been raving about this place for a year and was so happy to be back.This is a MUST when in Chicago! I would come back here tomorrow if I could =/

While Pequod's already have 1,000+ reviews, like Hot Doug's, I had to sing their praises! Hands down, the best deep dish pizza in Chicago. Hands down, the best environment to eat deep dish pizza in Chicago. You can be assured that there will be a wait of at least 45 minutes every time you come here, but it is totally worth it. The quality of ingredients and specialty crust puts Pequod's above the likes Lou's, Giordano's, & Gino's East. While the aforementioned are fine estabilshments that I also enjoy, I'd rather go to Pequod's anytime. They have a cool environment as well, with TV's everywhere and memorabilia adorning the walls. The location in the heart of Lincoln Park doesn't hurt. While Bourdain is partially correct that the only time Chicagoans eat deep dish is when visitors are in town, he's COMPLETELY FULL OF BOLOGNA when he says that deep dish sucks. Deep dish is amazing and so much better than your greasy shitpile New York slice. Who are we kidding, Chicago anything is better than the New York version. GO PEQUODS!

When I was in Chicago I felt like it was only right that I try a deep dish. I asked around and seriously every single person I asked told me about this place. And I am so glad I took their advice.I came on an early afternoon for lunch and we were seated fairly quickly. But by the time we had left the place was packed and there was a line of people waiting to get in. The location I went to had two levels decent size plenty of space not to crowded. I went with a their classic deep dish with sausage, peppers, onions, mushrooms and garlic. I do have to say it does take a little bit of time for the pizza to come out, a tad bit longer than I had expected considering the place wasn't that busy when we had place our order. But when it came out it was looking lovely. I can not speak highly enough about this pizza. It wasn't a typical deep dish I was expecting it was almost a cross between a deep and a new york style. Super crispy crust and not too deep of a pizza. The crust is actually burnt cheese !! which tasted amazing. But yeah I loved how it wasn't that 8 inch deep deep dish I feel anyone not from Chicago would imagine. I was actually able to have more than one slice. The pizza was delicious and everything was cook perfectly. Definitely understand why so many people pointed me in this direction. Probably the best deep dish in Chicago.

Figuring where to park almost led us not to go here.  We found a spot,  and once inside the staff was very friendly,  so that was a nice start. We were seated quickly,  but came in between lunch and dinner,  so not a huge crowd.  It definitely picked up as we were leaving.  We loved the pizza,  the crust was delicious and has such a great crunchy bite.  My niece got a thin single slice and I thought it was a little soft for a thin crust,  but she enjoyed it. I would definitely come here again,  service was quick and friendly. Barnes and Noble had validated parking for 3 hours if you shop there,  but the machine that does the validation is towards the front of the store,  so you can probably be sneaky lol.
Excellent - fav deep dish in Chicago. A place locals go, or so I;m told.

Pequod's is the place to be if you are a crust lover. It's flavorful. It has just the right amount of crunch - crackly when you bite into it, but not too hard to cut through. But best of all is the caramelized cheese at the end...those crunchy burnt bites were the perfect end to my meal!For non-crust-lovers, I could see how Pequod's might be a tad disappointing; it is a classic pizza joint so with standard fillings (sausage, pepperoni, spinach, mushroom...). The marinara is balanced but not awe-inspiring (though how inspiring can marinara be?). I was pleased to see that our sausage was cut into thick, hearty slices.For me, though, Pequod's more than makes up for their lack of innovative flavors in that crispy, cheesy crust!
Holy wow the best deep dish Chicago pie I have ever had! The longest I have ever had to wait to be sat and fed but was totally worth it! Highly recommended

If anyone ever comes to visit Chicago and wants deep dish, this is the only place I take them and it's always a hit.The perfect deep dish pizza consists of: Beef, giardiniera, and spinach. That's all you need... and a party in your mouth. Yum.
Amazing deep dish pizza at a great price. I got a person pan with 1/2 sausage, absolutely wonderful!!
Best deep dish pizza in Chicago. I love the crust and how its slightly burnt. No other pizza is comparable any where. Expect long waits on weekends and game night. parking can be difficult too.

Favorite pan/deep dish pizza place in Chicago (and I'm tried Gino's East, Lou Malnati's, and Giordano's). Crust is one of the most important parts of the pizza to me, and the caramelized crust here is the best! We order the pan pizza with peppers and tomatoes. The pizzas here are larger and less expensive than the other deep dish pizza places in Chicago. They also deliver to a wide radius and always arrive before they say they will arrive. We will be ordering our deep dish pizza here for every Chicago birthday! Pequod's Lincoln Park has been here since the 1970s. Very cool! Tip: We biked here, and there are poles outside to lock your bike to that are safe.

To be honest, I was growing tired and bored with Deep dish pizza...but then I found Pequod's. This place blows Lou Malnati's and every other deep dish pizza I've eaten out of the water!!! I'm going to make this short and sweet cause I will be re-reviewing this place in the future...Pizza is thick, excellent sauce(perfect blend of flavor and some sweetness), excellent amount of cheese,  the sausage needs to be on each and every pizza, AND the crust is the BEST part (does not look the part but it is chewy heaven in your mouth). Great service and decent beer selection as well. GO here and grab some excellent pie for great prices.

Fantastic pie! Had the deep dish with shrooms, green peppers, onions and meatball. It was awesome! I especially loved how the toppings are a top the sauce like a traditional thin is. Makes you really appreciate the toppings more than if they were in the middle with the cheese. and the caramelized crust is delish. It's like they put a thin rim of cheese around the cruse and burn it to a golden brown.Ambiance is nice and divey, server was cute and attentive and the bill wasn't too bad though a little pricey. (Dinner for 3 with 2 drinks each, tax and tip $83.)I'd definitely go back. Haven't had Uno's yet but overall this is the best pizza so far.

Wow!  If you're like me and not a fan of traditional Chicago Deep Dish this is a variant you might want to try.  I personally see this as more of a pan style pizza than a deep dish due to the fluffier thicker crust.  Aside from the great sauce and structure of the pizza the biggest draw is the caramelized cheese ring around the perimeter of the pizza.  It has to be tasted to be understood.  At first your brain wants to think: "Crap, you burned my f'n pizza!" However it's by design.  Originally founded by Burt Katz of Gulivers and Burt's Place fame this place has to be tried.  Periods was sold by Burt many years ago but the pizza is still his design.  If you want a table get there at 5 or 5:30 or be prepared to wait over an hour especially on weekends.

People outside Chicago have this idea that Chicagoans live on Lou Malnati's and Giordano's deep dish. I feel like it's my mission in life to let the world know, for one, real Chicagoans actually get thin crust at Giordano's, and two, if I'm getting anything thicker than that, is HAS to be Pequod's, in all the burnt cheesy crust glory there is to be had in this world. You want to eat real pizza in Chicago? This is where you go. Pequod's isn't shy with toppings, or sauce, and the cheesy crust is out of this world. Here's what you need to know about Pequods:-You will wait over an hour on Saturday night without a reservation; get reservations, or call ahead for takeout (unless you like waiting)-They have great lunch specials-Delivery zone is pretty wide-It's in Lincoln Park, but parking is pretty decent (no lot)-Goose Island on tapTaste it for yourself.

I love pizza, so I was very excited to try a Chicago deep dish pizza. I googled where to go and I found this place . It wasn't very busy when I went in with my family . We got seated immediately ( even with a party of 10).   We started with an appetizer combo(9$) which went fast, which didn't feel worth it but we did have 10 people share it . Then we orders 2 large pizzas (17.99 each just cheese .almost 2 dollars per additional topping) . The wait was 30 mins which was understandable since it's a deep dish and takes long to cook.  So worth the wait! We didn't even finish the pizza( 2 slices left) because we were so full ! I loved the crust, I just wish it had more cheese. I already ordered extra cheese I just wanted more  Our server was very polite !She was awesome and was quick with everything, she always keep us updated with the pizza time ! One thing I found odd was that she wasn't in any sort of uniform, so she just looked like a regular guest  in a oversized sweater . Overall I really enjoyed my experience , it was my first time trying any Chicago style deep dish and look forward to comparing different places to find the best one for me

Amazing deep dish. Compared to Lou Malnati's, the bread is definitely thicker, but the crust is so much more flavorful and enjoyable. Instead of basically a giant plate of sausage, you get your normal balls of sausage at Pequod's. Got two personal pizzas with sausage and extra marinara, which was the perfect amount for 2-3 people. We asked for less dough because we were afraid that the pizza would be too bready for us, and it ended up being the right choice. The marinara is phenomenal, the sausages delectable, and the crust is a glorious crown of crisp cheesiness. Definitely a place to stop by if you're visiting Chicago.

For pizza amateurs and enthusiasts alike, I implore you to make the trip to Pequod's.  It's Chicago's best known secret located in the northwest suburbs.  Their breed of pizza is still of the deep dish variety, but different in way's that make this establishment my second/third favorite pizza in Chicago. (First being Lou Malnati's)For $21.40, I ordered a medium sized pizza (6 Slices), with pepperoni and sausage.  Out of the 7 pizza parlors I visited, this place takes the longest to make, but your patience will be well rewarded.What makes Pequod's special:1)  The first thing everyone notices about a Pequod's pizza is the crust. It appears to be overly burnt, but it's actually a thin layer of cheese that was baked onto the crust. While the resulting flavor is decent and slightly charred, the texture is phenomenol--the caramelized cheese gives the back of the pie a delightful chewiness that doesn't exist in any pizza2) Pequod's has the BEST toppings I ever had in my life.  The sausage is in meatball form but is so tender it almost crumbles before you bite into it.  As for the taste, it's dynamic.  Full of flavor and bursting with seasonings that'll leave you dazed.  Same can be said about their pepperoni.  There's also an added crispness to them that makes me believe they broil their meat before serving.As for the sauce, it's sweeter than most, but less chunky.  I felt it interplayed well with the salty, thick toppings.  The cheese is basic mozzarella and has sufficient ooey-gooey goodness for any cheese lover.  I actually feel the pizza tastes better as a whole once the cheese congeals to the toppings as there is a lot of "cheese-sliding" when it comes out hot.  In measurements of depth, it's a thick pizza with about a 1.3 inches deep.----Conclusion: Pequod's continues to receive local and national honors of being the best pizza. Although I can see the reason for the accolades, I still feel Lou Malnati's wins by a hair.  Reason being, Lou's characterizes, to me, what deep dish is about: A layering of delicious flavors that is so deep and so stuffed, it resembles lasagna.  Pequod's is made in the format of a traditional pizza, with unique differences in quality and crust.  Overall, it's a definite must-try during your trip and something all food/pizza lovers should indulge in. Extra Notes:-Accepts credit card-$4.95 Yelp Check-in Lunch special of a Cheese personal pizza-Adam Richman (Man VS Food) favorite pizza joint in America-Atmosphere leans more on the chill side and decor seems aged, but less touristy. - Wait times are long and it does get crowded-Servers are very friendly and suggestive-Significantly further from downtown, but take the OTA off madison&clinton and exit at Clybourn. Walk north for about 10 minutes until you get to Webster and turn right. An Uber will cost about $18-Restrooms are clean
Awesome nom noms.The pies were delicious.Recommend calling them ahead of time if you want to pick up. Otherwise it's a 45 minute wait in perfection.
Favorite pizza place in Chicago. Can't get enough of the Pan pizza... drool

Crust is my favorite. I keep going back and forth between this and Lou's being my favorite. Pizza alone, Pequod's may win, but sides and salads don't compare to Lou's. Wish they had more locations...must try for deep dish.

An hour and half wait then 40 min wait for pizza? Normally, I would say hell to the no. But in this rare, rare occasion, the wait was worth it!! And I never, ever say that! This pizza is beyond amazing. The crust is airy and not too dense and cheese, oh lord the cheese is incredible. Again, totally worth it!!

This is the best deep dish pizza! I have to get it every time I go to Chicago. This time I went for lunch and the lunch special is on point! The side salad you get, I would not recommend wasting 2$ or however much it was because it was just some iceberg and cucumbers. The crust is like burnt carmelized cheese, I dream about this pizza and can't wait to go back to Chicago to have it. You have to get sausage on it!
I'm from NY and a bit of a pizza snob.  I was never a fan of Chicago style pizza until I ate here.   The small is big enough for 2 to share and was VERY GOOD!

The perfect local deep dish! Better than all the chain/touristy spots.I am a big fan of deep dish pizza, but I usually and left with the chain restaurants or a store that makes deep dish taste like a block of cheese or tomato puree.  Not the case here. Pequod's is perfect! It has full flavor and lots of toppings options and is reasonably priced. The venue is also really comfortable and neighborly. I am always going to get my deep dish pizza here.

Pequod's is hands down my favorite pizza place in Chicago. The thin and pan pizzas are both excellent but the pan caramelized crust is the shining gem amongst all deep dish out there. My NY boyfriend is very picky with his pizza (and not usually a fan of deep dish) but we equally love it and always bring our visitors here. The wait (both to sit and for your pizza) can add up during peak hours so it's better to come before 6. Regardless it is worth the wait. If you haven't tried it yet, do yourself the favor!
Love this place!  Best pizza ever.  Priced right as well!

Have had on numerous occasions.  Fantastic always.  The crust is quite possibly better than Lou Mals butter crust.  I go back and forth continuously.  One thing that puts this place ahead of Lous is the amount of toppings they put on.  It is ridiculous in a great way.  Order it well done.   Favorite thick/pan pizza in America.  Keep up the good work.
Best deep dish in Chicago. Maybe the world. Long wait times but it is worth every minute. A must every time I'm in the Windy City.
The first time I went, the crust tasted amazing! The second time I went the pizza was ok! I personally think the pizza needs more sauce! This place is open until around 2am and is casual.
The lunch special is $5 caramelized personal pizza at the skokie location is a must have- bucket list worthy.

Among my hometown Chicago friends, Pequod's is the #1 recommendation for deep dish BESIDES the chains (Lou's, Giordano's, etc.). And why? The crust. It's great. Unfortunately, I think they simply under-season their pizza. The rest of the pie ends up a little bit bland for my taste, especially given the slightly inflated price (relative to the chains mentioned above). That said, if you're going out for deep dish (versus ordering in/picking up), this is one of the best places to do that - the environment is comfortable and kitschy in only the right ways.

Pequod's may have the best pizza that I have ever had! I was a visitor to Chicago and liked the reviews that I had read about this restaurant. My wife and I arrived and we're seated fairly soon because we called ahead for priority seating. We ordered a medium deep dish pepperoni pizza and I thought it was phenomenal.

Ask 5 people in the city what their favorite pie is in Chicago and I would bet that 4 would say Pequod's. When people come to visit from out of town, this place is my go-to for the pizza portion on their trip.

Our daughters swear this is the best pizza.It is very very good.Service is very good.Street parking is difficult.The decor is Chicago bar / pizza place.Price point is just fine.Definitely not heart healthy, but I recommend if you are in the area.

came here on my visit to Chicago since everyone swear by it. I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza due to the tomato sauce, I normally get the white sauce pizza because the red sauce is a bit sour for me. However I could actually enjoy the pizza here as the sauce is not sour, and everything together makes it quite delicious. Call ahead so you don't have to wait for hours and also place your pizza order over the phone because those deep deep dish pizza takes over an hour to make especially when it's busy.

I've been to the other Chicago pizza staple joints but I was told I had to try Pequods.Lincoln Park area was quite a bit north of our downtown hotel location but my wife and I had time to kill and thought we may as well visit since we're in town. This place was definitely worth the visit. It's not fancy, but who cares? It definitely has its own character, which is what we love in a local joint. The pizza is fantastic. You can choose thin crust or deep dish. We opted for the deep dish because, hey, we're in Chicago. They also advertise their crust as being carmelized due to the blackened dish they bake it in. The top edge of the crust turns black as well which makes it unique. If you are looking for a Chicago deep dish experience and have not tried Pequods yet, what are you waiting for??

Pequod's is Chicago's best pizza. That's it. I've grown up in Chicago my entire life and have had the best thin, pan and deep dish all over the city. When it comes to pan pizza, Pequod's is the place. The crust is caramelized and crunchy, the pizza has just the right amount of cheese and sauce. A lot of places either put too much sauce or too much cheese, but the ratio is perfection here. The pepperoni gets a crisp on the edges, too. Even when the place was packed, the wait wasn't too long -- 30 minutes. There are so many seats here, with two bars and two floors of seating, you won't be waiting too long (at least from my experience).

By far the absolute best pizza in Chicago.I am not originally from here but I feel as though once you've had this pizza, you are allowed to be a snob because I'd venture to say that this is the pizza the creators of deep dish pizza had in mind on that fateful day.Pequods is open late which is obviously the sign of an amazing pizza place, all of the employees are very friendly and the restaurant is always clean.The pizza takes a little long (which is expected) but wow is it worth the wait!!! They have a full bar so you are able to keep the party going or get the party started! The best part is that no one tells you how to have your pizza party so you can pick the toppings!The restrooms are very clean which is super important and not to mention there is more than one!PS the pizza is amazing when reheated... And boy do we love having those leftovers.

Pequod's is definitely not overrated.  The pan pizza is so good!  Two of us ordered a medium, and it was enough for us to each have 2 slices (and leave so stuffed) and then have another 2 slices to take home.I love that the crust is still crunchy on the bottom.  This is something that other pizzerias haven't mastered.  Giordano's has long been my favorite "Chicago" pizza, because I love cheese (and more cheese), but Pequod's has them beat.  I was appalled at the idea of burnt crust, but somehow it works.  Sorry Lou's, you've got major competition too!We also shared a half salad - the Pequod's salad.  The slices of provolone are shaped like little whales *squeal*!The beer menu is decent, but the pricing was a little more craft beer bar than local pizza place.  I had a Goose Island Green Line for $6.  You can request a table on their website - and it's foolish if you don't do this for a Saturday night.  My request was for 5:30, but because of the snow and traffic, we didn't get here until closer to 6:00 p.m.  When we arrived, I told the hostess about our reservation, but we were handed a pager and informed of a 10 minute wait.   We were seated at the worst possible table in the place.  During our entire meal, patrons were shoving by as they crowded in the "waiting" area, which is essentially maybe ten square feet of floor in front of the hostess stand.  I got elbowed in the back a few times, sometimes it was inevitable and some people apologized.  Others didn't and were too consumed with grouching about their wait.  Even the servers had trouble getting through the crowd!  If you can, get a seat as far away from the door as possible.  I'm happy that even though we were late, we got a seat quickly, but the layout sucks and Pequod's is best avoided during peak times unless you're placing a carryout order.The mascot still has me confused.  I don't know what a whale with...is that a thong on it's face?...has to do with pizza.

I had this right when I landed in Chicago and it was absolutely amazing!! It's by far the best deep dish pizza I ever had. I ordered the pizza half pepperoni and half sausage with mushrooms and bell peppers. The sausage and pepperoni tasted like it was freshly made. I loved the amount of marinara sauce on the pizza. The best part was the crisp cheese on the crust! It was so good, I had to get it again 3 days later :) if I'm ever in town, I don't think I'll go to any other pizzeria (tried Lou Malnati's a day later and prefer Pequod's).
eat's up food critics! an abundance of words is not needed to explain this 8th wonder of the world. the deep dish with a caramelized crust was baked to perfection. that is all. a must go.

Pizza was good,  it was just more crust than toppings.  Able to split a10" for two people and not get overly stuffed. Great atmosphere, and our plan to go mid - afternoon on a Saturday worked well with only a 15 minute wait time.

Amazing pizza, even worth bearing its sports bar bro ambiance. It wasn't quite as heavy as other Chicago deep dish I've had, which was refreshing. The crust is what made it different.We arrived at 6:15 on a Saturday night and waited an hour and fifteen minutes for pizza, which was noted on a sign before we ordered. Of course this varies, but plan accordingly if you are on a schedule. Ordering an appetizer, which arrived in about fifteen minutes, helped!

Good pizza, love the burnt cheese crust but 90% of the pizza is bread as you will see if some of the customer pictures...it would be perfect if the fixed the ratio to be 50% bread, 25% cheese, and 25% sauce. Overall not bad but my favorite Chicago deep dish remains to be Lou Malnati's.Oh and don't sleep on the chocolate chip cookie. One of the best cookies I've had!

Pequods is my love. Their crust just gets me. So caramelized and delicious - so good. I would suggest going at an off time otherwise the wait time get pretty long. Getting it to-go just isnt the same for me but that's also an option. One of my favorite pizza places to eat at in Chicago.

Everyone in Chicago has a favorite place to get their deep dish pizza, and when I first started the bf he was all "You've never had Pequod's? That's just crazy! We're going." I used to think maybe deep dish just wasn't my thing, but it was because I'd never had Pequod's! From the caramelized crust, to the ooey gooey cheesiness, to the little morsels of pineapple paired with canadian bacon - did ya forget I'm a Hawaiian pizza freak? - I've never been disappointed and I will always pick Pequod's as my fave when anyone inquires. In 4+ year love affair with  Pequod's, I'd never been to this location, but on my last trip to Chicago this was the most convenient, so off we went. We called in and ordered for takeout about 45 minutes before we'd be able to get there and upon our arrival there were dozens of people outside waiting just to get inside to order their pizza. From waiting in line to pay to being handed the yummiest pizza possible, we waited about 10 minutes, if that. Obviously they're doing it right over at Pequod's!

"I'm a thin crust girl," I've always said.Well, after visiting Chicago...not anymore. Day two in the Windy City, I had Giordano's which was delicious, but day four with Pequod's blew every other pizza I've ever had out of the water. Pepperoni, pineapple, giardiniera. Ohmygoshhh. I'm back in Texas and still cannot stop daydreaming about this dang pizza.

You always hear about the battle between Gino's, Lou Malnatis and Giordano's for the title of "Best Deep Dish Pizza in Chicago." They are all awesome, but Pequod's gives you a different taste of Chicago deep dish pizza. Instead of a mountain of cheese (which is awesome) their deep dish pizza is made deep with fluffy, crisp, cooked to perfection dough. I wish our experience with the service had been better. We had ordered a salad, which never came. Perhaps going on a weekday would provide better service when it is less crowded. The surrounding area is also fun to explore!
Carmelized crusts.  Nuff said.Be prepared to wait.If you get a booth and order some beers, the 45 min wait doesn't seem that bad, and the closeness of the group makes every night a fun outing.

Pequod's was an unexpectedly fantastic deep dish.  Unexpected because I'd never heard of it, and it may be the best deep dish I've ever had!I had a deep dish with pepperoni, pineapple, and extra sauce which would not normally be my first choice, but was absolutely delicious.  I'm told it can be slightly dry on sauce without the extra order, so give that a shot if you feel like something is missing.  The cheesy burnt crust was also an amazing surprise as I don't normally like burnt anything, especially cheese but it too was fantastic!Next time I go back I'm going to have to try  Italian Beef and Jalapeno or Hot Giardiniera!I'll keep the review simple since I had delivery - order it, chow it, sleep it off, repeat.
Awesome deep dish pizza and great service! Definitely coming back here again! This is nos my favorite deep dish pizza now.

Ate here for the 2nd time a few days ago!! Best deep dish I had so far- beats Giordanos any day. The pizza comes out super hot. The cheese is absolutely amazing, so creamy, melts right off the pizza. I only tried the deep dish pizza pie and it's to die for!The reason for the 4 stars, however, as follows:They get pretty busy so service can be a little slow. First time our waitress was still great, despite how busy it was. The second time we came here we felt a little ignored and forgotten. Also, if you like a lot of toppings, can come out pretty expensive. They charge about 3 extra dollars PER topping. I love my toppings, so our pizza pie went from $18 to about $46!!! Nevertheless, totally worth it! Will come here whenever I absolutely need a, to die for, Chicago style deep dish. Worth the 1 hr drive here for me!

Best deep dish "Chicago style" pizza in the world. Friendly staff, service is good, pizza takes 45min+ to cook, so make sure you have time. Really well priced bc You only need 1 slice, maybe 2 if your a heavy eater. Highly recommend!!

Incredible pizza. The crust is a thing of beauty, like fresh baked bread but caramelized and seamlessly integrated into the rest of the pizza. The wait times and limited space in the restaurant are the only drawbacks.

My favorite pizza in the city, yep even better than Lou Malnati's which I never thought I would say about any deep dish ever. Love love LOVE this place. Gets CRAZYYYYY packed though so watch out for that and plan ahead of time during cubs games.
In my opinion, best pizza in Chicago. I love the crust and I would recommend it to anyone! May take a bit long but definitely worth it.

Right off the plane and first on my list was pequods! This place seems busy but the wait isn't too bad. There is street parking a little further away, so you'll have to do a little walking. I had the lunch special, one personal cheese deep dish pizza and salad. Plus a side order of buffalo wings. The buffalo wings came out first and it was great, small crispy wings. The pizza didn't come out til 30 mins later. I wasn't t aware it would take so long until I over heard the waitress at the table next to us saying it takes 30 mins to cook. It was totally worth the wait tho. That crispy edge with over flowing cheese was soooo good. I'd fly back just for this! I didn't try any other deep dish pizzas in town because the pictures and reviews for other restaurants just didn't compare.

Yummy, yummy, yummy I got Pequods in my belly.  Everyone is totally jelly.Caramelized cheese crust is a must!  I eat it til I bust!Toppings galore...nothing here is a bore.Had takeout, so I don't know what the restaurant is about!

I've been a loyal fan of Lou's deep dish my whole life... Until I tried this place.  Holy crap.  AMAZING. It was super crowded and we waited almost an hour for our table, but it was well worth it.The burnt cheesie crust is like nothing I've ever tasted before.  I never thought pizza could be a life changing experience, but here we are.
This is a must stop when I visit Chicago. The pizza is absolutely amazing. Love the thick crust. Crispy, flavorful.  Sauce is awesome. Always packed with pizza lovers. Try the meatball sandwich.

Go right now! Seriously, stop whatever you're doing and head to be Pequod's.This might just be the best pizza I've ever had in my whole life! I didn't get to eat at Lou's this time so I'm not sure I can compare. The ratio of sauce to crust to toppings is perfect, I'm not sure what people are complaining about on here. If you love deep dish pizza, then this is perfect for you.The pepperoni on top is razor thin so the pieces on the top were almost like a chip they were crunchy. I picked them all off and still have plenty of pepperoni that were soft left behind. There was an ample amount of toppings as I got pepperoni and pineapple on top of the $4.95 cheese special they have at lunch. Which by the way, also includes a beverage. Such a deal! You pay $.80 extra for each additional toppings.I also spend the extra $2.50 on a salad, just because I eaten total junk food this week and thought that might be good for me. The salad was tiny but good. They make their own ranch and Italian.It's so hard to explain the crust that people are talking about on here, the cheese on the outside is amazing, it doesn't taste burnt at all, it's just crispy goodness.  Each of the pizzas is cooked in its own cast-iron skillet.The sauce is perfect. It's a great complement to the crust and the toppings, unlike some other places in Chicago, it doesn't overrule the entire pie.Really, I think if I lived in Chicago, I would have to get a job at this place as the person that eats the crust that anybody leaves behind when they're finished. I guess I'll have to pay them too. I doubt they'll pay me. But really, it's that good!!!!!

I mean I don't know what else I can really add to the accolades that have been heaped upon Pequod's for years.  I first visited in 2008 and it was instant love.  Since then I've ordered delivery off and on over the years.  It was my recent move out of their delivery zone (literally just a couple blocks, c'mon guys!!!! Hook a brother up) that finally forced me back to the brick and mortar.  Dear god, I'm an idiot.  It's so much better in the shop than delivery.  The perfect crunchiness on the bottom of the crust for the pan pizza simply can't be maintained the same when you have it delivered.  I love this place, it is consistently the best pizza in Chicago.
My favorite pizza in Chicago. Super crowded and loud but worth it!

I've been coming to Pequod's chicago for over 10 years now and hands down, Pequods has the best pizza in Chicago!!!! I'm not one for pan pizza or deep dish (as i tend to enjoy thin crust more....) but this place absolutely does pizza right.  The carmelized cheese crust is what makes this pizza the best.  Best times to go are during the weekdays (if you can get the time off!).  Parking is a bit difficult on the street but worth the drive up to Chicago.  They have a second location in the North suburbs if you live near morton grove.  Both places are great and worth your time if you want great pizza at inexpensive prices.
By far the best deep dish pizza in Chicago!! Blows the competitors out, but keep in mind this shows in the delivery time! Be ready to order 2 hours before you want some pizza!

Pequod's pizza is my husband's favorite deep dish in the city and of course I had to check it out! I went on a Wednesday night and two people on a date can get seated in 20 minutes or less! The restaurant is actually larger than it appears on the outside and they have lots of tables and booths for groups or just couples. What I did not realize was the pizza crust is burnt, which is apparently their thing. It doesn't have a burnt taste, but it is flavorful and the sauce is more runny than chunky tomato. Pequod's definitely has more of a unique neighborhood-local vibe that you don't find with most other deep dishes places in Chicago which seem more chain-y. I found the pizza to be a little greasier than expected with a deep dish and expect another 20 minute wait time for the deep dish. We ordered a large between the two of us and only at 1-2 slices. Large is LARGE and filling at Pequod's. I ended up feeling sick after eating it tho but that may have just been my own fault. I gave this a four star because of the grease and the small drink list.
Love it, so different than the typical deep dish which I love as well. Great taste you won't get anywhere else!

Of course you had to get deep dish in Chicago. My friend has tried all the popular ones but all her local friends say that this is the best one. Unfortunately this is not really close to downtown so you have to uber it there. It says that it closes at midnight but I think it was open and there was a sign that said til 1-1:30am. So we had a 11pm dinner and it takes about 30-45 minutes to make it. You get to make your own so we got two deep dish: One large with sausage and pepperoni and the other with mushroom and spinach split along 6 people. I thought it was pretty good and quite filling. Now I am not a deep dish type of girl because I want to taste all the ingredients instead of a pile of tomato sauce. Two larges was a lot for a group of six since the crust is so damn thick and filling so maybe a large and medium for a group like ours. I cant tell if it is better or not than the next since they sorta taste the same.

Being new to Chicago, I was told prior to my move that Giordano's was the place to go for deep dish. Working at a Two Michelin Star Restaurant molecular cooks said that Pequod's is the place to go for a good pizza. It certainly is, the flavors accent one another in a way that is extraordinary. The caramelized crust makes it unlike anything else you'll find in Chicago. Definitely making the trip to Lincoln Park whenever I'm in the mood for pizza.

Landed in Chicago and this was the first stop I made at 11PM on a Friday night. There were three of us and we were seated promptly without a reservation. It was quite packed however, and we were brought upstairs for additional seating. Definitely a divey vibe with the dim lighting and neon signs. We went ahead and just ordered a medium pan pizza with pepperoni, sausage, and mushrooms. This is probably just common sense but don't come hungry because obviously deep dish will take a while to bake and we were dying of hunger waiting for that pie to come out. When it finally arrived at our table, it was glorious. The cheese, the sauce, the MEAT (sausage was so good!!) , the crust all came together to become a symphonic meal. I'm a deep dish noob, so I was taken aback by just how monstrous it was. I was barely able to finish my two slices of pizza, which is pretty shameful for me. Basically, the first piece was heaven, the second piece was a little less enjoyable because I was already strangely full and the crust wasn't as crispy. I was also surprised by the sauce to dough ratio because I had this preconception that Chicago deep dish would be very saucey. I was wrong. Not too mad about it because it clearly works for this pie. I probably wouldn't frequent this place if I lived in Chicago, but I'm very glad I got to try it while I was there!

I hit up Lou's and Pequod's on my recent trip to Chicago and I have to admit Pequod's wins. It was a much more satisfying pizza that was still tasty on the flight home the next day.We ordered a sausage and giardiniera on our pie and they were fantastic. Quick comparison, Lou's has a thinner style crust that is formed into an pan and is really crispy and a thick layer of fresh cheese and a hearty very fresh tasting sauce, not very greasy even with the buttered crust. Pequod's on the other hand is a thicker crust formed into the pan that is amazingly flavorful and juicy, The cheese is dripping off the edge of the pie and is much more of your decadent style pizza cheese. The house made sausage is not as fully loaded across the pie as Lou's does but it is everywhere and it is very tasty and you can tell it is made fresh. The sauce is not as hearty as Lou's but is more flavorful (in my opinion). The giardiniera was this awesomely spicy little Italian pepper that really provided a great kick of spicy to the pizza. Think more long hots flavor than jalapeno. Finally, I think the caramelized crust wins over the buttered crust hands down. It is an awesome layer of crispy deliciousness!. It was worth trying both since it was my first time there but on my next visit it is Pequod's or bust. Side note: call ahead and get your name on the list. They don't do reservations but you can call on your way over because this place is packed and even after your wait it takes 35 minutes for your pies to cook. But that is the nature of the deep dish pies.

Absolutely unforgettable and delicious. I cannot believe I've lived in Chicago for 8 and 1/2 years and never tried It !  The atmosphere is cozy and darker, which is what I prefer. The staff is extremely friendly and PROUD of where they work. Our server was very excited that we were trying the pizza for the first time. We were starving so we also sampled almost every appetizer (mostly the fried stuff!). Lots of tasty dipping sauces :) Everything came out in a timely fashion and our drinks were never empty.It was busy because it was the same weekend as Riot Fest but I don't think we had to wait longer than 20 minutes for our table. We were able to find a spot at the bar and enjoy some strong drinks while we waited.Hands down, it's the best deep dish pizza I've ever had in Chicago.  I like it because the crust is light and fluffy instead of resembling pie crust. I can actually eat more than once piece at Pequods! If you have guests from out of town who want to try deep dish, skip all of the downtown places and go to Pequod's .

Amazing deep dish pizza! My bf and I had the pan pizza with sausage, pepperoni and spinach! It is a little pricey for extra toppings but overall, it was worth it! I'll definitely recommend this to everyone!

Went here on our last night in town and since Chicago is known for their deep dish I had to go to the best.  Read this was the best deep dish in town. I'm not a deep dish person but when in Rome, right?  We came for dinner and there was quite the wait. We ended up finding seats at the bar so we ordered our pie. We shared the small which was more than enough. One slice filled me up and we actually had to take the rest home. Overall a good pizza joint.

So I finally had a chance to try the Pe of the Quod at a co-worker get-together recently and I must say: not being a big deep dish pizza fan myself (I know.. I am clearly an extraterrestrial since I'm from Chicago and not a deep dish fan) this was hands-down the best deep-dish pizza I've ever had. The pizza was cooked perfectly, a cheesy masterpiece, and very flavorful overall. The service was outstanding and the atmosphere of the place energetic and fun.Final Verdict:If I find myself, on the rare occasion that it is, hankering for some deep dish pizza - I can't see myself going anywhere but to Pequod's!

Ordered a small pan pizza and it was delicious. I have to say the place isn't the most consistent in terms of taste. My first experience left me disappointed, but with another go at it I was pleasantly surprised at how good it tasted. I was disappointed with the portion size because me and my lady-friend were still feeling hungry. We were fooled into thinkng the pizza was "good for 1-2 people." Aside from consistency and portion size, the staff were friendly and not intrusive, the prices were fair, and crust was great

My personal favorite pizza restaurant in Chicago, the service is good and it's a Blackhawks fan's dream. This is a great date restaurant especially if you pick the spot because it's always a hit. I love the people who work there. They are very busy but still manage to make you feel special.It does take a while to get your Pizza but it's worth it, so plan your time wisely, relax and enjoy this amazing restaurant.Martha Daniel

I love my thin crust pizza, but when in Chicago...I had a personal deep dish pizza and it arrived in front of me, piping hot, fresh out of the oven. First bite... "Damn... that's good." This was the first time I've ever REALLY enjoyed a deep dish pizza. I loved the burnt cheese on the edges, too!We sat at the bar and the bartender was really pleasant and quick with our drinks, so I appreciated that.Will be back!

In a disappointing search to find deep dish Chicago style pizza I was blessed by the pizza gods to make it the Pequod's on my last night in town. The pizza was everything I could have hoped for. If I would have found this place earlier there's a chance I would've eaten every meal here for the whole week.

Review is for delivery (food) only, so cannot comment on the ambiance.  Pizza is very good, deep pan pizza.  Toppings are applied with a heavy hand, crust is crispy on the outside and everything arrived on time.  Important to note, this is pan pizza (more similar to Lou Malnati's, Gino's) and not Chicago-style stuffed pizza (i.e. Bacinos, Giordanos).

There's nothing like having deep dish on A cold winter day right after picking out a Christmas tree at a local tree lot. That's my favorite memory of Pequods because it was my first experience at delicious deep dish! Now over a year later it has become one of my MANY favorite pizza stops in Chicago. I also highly recommend their jalapeño poppers... I don't like jalapeños and still ogle over them! Service is normal, sometimes great, sometimes average!

Very tasty! Visiting from out of town and given many recommendations of where to get deep dish, but Pequod's was the most recommended from friends. Not disappointed at all. We were told it would be a 20 minute wait, but were seated in less than 15. The appetizer combo was not bad - the jalepeno poppers were the best, so I think I would have just gone with those.Our deep dish was super yummy and surprisingly not too heavy. I've had deep dish before that left me feeling  uncomfortably full, but this deep dish was filling without the gross greasy feeling afterwards. We got mushrooms and fresh garlic toppings that were very fresh and delicious. I'll definitely come back next time I'm in town.

As my friend (Angie G.) took me around Chicago as a tourist, I was so excited to try this place! She ranted and raved that it was the best pizza I would ever put in my mouth. We ordered a big deep dish. I believed we ordered some sort of meat lover's special and she ordered the giardenara and pineapple. I had some of both and both were AMAZING. The taste was spot on, cooked to perfection, and it came out piping hot. The downside to this place is the wait time. It does take a long time for the pizzas to come out! However, I don't really mind this because I know my pizza was made to order. WARNING: I recently went back for a second visit during the lunch hour. I ordered a "personal pizza". OMG. Horrible. Do not order the personal pizzas. Stick to the big deep dish, their specialty! A night and day difference, I tell you.The service was good; the vibe is like a sports bar. A "chill" pizza joint where you can have a genuinely good time over pizza and beer. Go!
Thin, crispy, tasty.  Maybe the best pizza in Chicago.

Don't think it looks like much from the outside? Haven't you ever heard the saying, don't judge a book by its cover? I had lived near here for months and  I can't tell you how many times I passed this place without ever thinking twice - that is until I heard just about every single one of my friends mention it.So I broke down to check it out and I'm so glad I did. The night I was there both floors were filled with a diverse clientele including young couples on a casual date night, college kids coming in for a study break, and large parties with three generations of family members all enjoying the food, college football, and atmosphere. The pizza was phenomenal, especially the sauce and the crust sets it apart from some of the other standard Chicago pizza favs. I personally love the fact that you get the idea this was once someone's home turned into a pizza joint that still makes you feel as comfortable as if you were in someone's home.It has become one of my all-time favorite Chicago pizzas!

Kept asking around all the locals and uber drivers where the best deep dish was and pequouds and lou malnatis were the names that kept coming up. I chose here because it seemed like the better place to drink a beer too. It didn't disappoint though. Great pizza!

Got a dope lunch special.  For $4.95 you get a personal pan pizza (7") and a fountain drink OR pint of Bud Light.   Hard to beat for 5 dollars you get a pizza and a beer.  Special is M-F 11am-3pm.  Place was pretty empty for a lunch period which was great for me.  I wasn't trying to wait long to be seated. Overall the pizza was really good.  For lunch and the value it was great.  The edges were slightly burnt a lil too much for my liking but the pizza itself had lots of flavor.  The sauce was perfect and it has more than enough ground beef on it for me.  They definitely weren't stingy with the toppings.  Beer - Bud Light from a tap.  Not hard to mess up LOL.Place is essentially a pizza parlor, not restaurant.  So if you are looking for something classier, go somewhere else.  But if you are like me and just want quality food, affordable food and have the option of getting a drink as well, Pequod's is the place.  Next time I go back I'll likely try something else and see how the bartender pours and I'll update my review. You see I said next time right... I'll be back.

My husband is obsessed with pizza, so when we were headed to Chicago for our engagement pictures, we had to stop at Pequods. We've tried all the other Chicago pizza places and this was next on our list. We really liked it. The crust is different. I believe it's caramelized. I was told to ask. For extra sauce and I'm so glad we did. Our only issue was the wait - super crowded and you can't make reservations. The appetizers were good too. We ordered the chicken fingers and fried mushrooms. This place is really popular in Chicago so get there early!

Long wait, but pretty worth it. My favorite element in pizza is the tomato sauce and pequods douse their pizzas in a deliciously sweet tomato sauce. Really like their cheese and the oven burnt crust was incredible. The dough component was just ok but overall good pizza can be found here. Loved that it was Blackhawks themed!One negative that sticks out was that the hostess seemed overworked. She crossed our name off the waitlist twice, messed up the number of people in our party, and we weren't seated until we went up to her a third time and asked how much longer the wait would be.

The third stop on the pizza tour and the second deep dish pizza we tried.  I got the pepperoni and the bf got spinach.  The pepperoni deep dish was absolutely the BEST pizza I've had during the entire trip in Chicago and the best deep dish pizza I'd ever had (well, out of about four different choices).  There was a decent amount of sauce with a perfectly caramelized crust.  I wish we ate here first so I wasn't so full of unsatisfactory pizza.  The place was pretty crowded and loud when we arrived.  We were seated upstairs but the tour guide had called ahead for our orders so the wait time wasn't long at all.  This is probably not the usual case though.  I would totally stop by on my next Chicago visit.

My 2nd favorite pizza place next to Giordonos!Came in on a Sunday night around 7PM and wait was about 15 minutes.I really like the bar vibe at this restaurant and sportsplaying in the background.Pizza was amazing! took about 40-45 minutes to bake a deep dishand they are super generous with the topping you order. Servicewas good too, nothing to complain about! definitely make a visit!

Deep dish ain't pizza; it's lasagna with bread. That's cool, though. It still tastes pretty good, and I've yet to meet a native Chicagoan who will fight to the death to defend his city's pizza as the finest creation known to man.That said, I've eaten my fair share of deep dish and figured it's always good to have a place in your back pocket for when the family and friends come to visit. I've done the big three gauntlet and Lou Malnati's is my winner. However, I asked around for the best "local" spot to grab a deep dish slice, and the answer came back Pequod's.Pequod's is small, grungy, and really looks like half a bar than serves pizza on the side. But aside from all that, Pequod's actually makes a rather nice pie. There's nothing special on the menu, just the basics. Start with a cheese, and ingredient your way up.I was already massively hungry, so we ordered jalapeno poppers to start. I'll take the cheddar/yellow/orange filling over cream cheese any day of the week, so Pequod's already got off the blocks well. Still not as good as Jack in the Box, which makes an incomparable popper. But good.Pequod's deep dish, unlike the Big 3, isn't overzealous with the bread. It's still a chore to eat, but for different reasons. Pequod's says it caramelizes its crust, but what that really means is they char it to a crisp. For a guy that loves blackened anything (especially char on brisket), I loved it. Aside from the char, the breading is thinner than the typical deep dish, and much easier to eat. The sauce is plentiful (another check mark in my book), and although I'd heard that Pequod's goes easy on the cheese, the white stuff was still overkill for me. The tomato sauce came extra sweet, almost, say, Pizza Hut style as opposed to the more pomodoro/crushed tomato sourish taste.

Hands down my favorite pizza! Introduced to this pizza a few months ago and now any time in Chicago I order it!  Really wish they delivered to Florida as I've been craving their cheese burnt crust -- mm mmm good! I would wait forever for this pizza!   If you're in Chicago or in the vicinity of the Chicagoland area, do yourself a favor and head over to Pequods!

Best chicago style pizza in the city. I don't always eat deep dish, but when I do, it is Pequod's. Take your out of town friends here or order for pick-up or delivery. Get gardinera on the pizza! Adds another dimension of Chicago flavor and heat!

Had a 9 hour layover in Chicago on my way to LA. Figured it would be inappropriate for me to spend a few hours in Chicago without having a deep dish pizza. After asking the locals, it seemed like this establishment had the best deep dish pizza in town... And it seems like they were right - it's hard to believe there's a better deep dish pizza.The crust was caramelized and incredibly delicious. The cheese... it was orgasmic... no better way to describe it. Each toppings (we got pepperoni, sausage and basil) were so flavourful, you can taste each one with every bite!The servers were very hospitable and friendly.Highly recommend this place!

This is the best pizza in Chicago. It's also a little off the beaten path, so it is mostly locals, which is nice.  It's still always busy and will generally have at least a 30 minute wait, but it's worth it.  Pro tip: Get the personal pizza, as it's about right for one hungry person and it maximizes the caramelized crust.  Also, their lunch special is the best deal in the city.  It used to be $4.95 for a personal pizza, salad and drink, though it may be a bit more now.

Giordano's has always been our Chicago pizza go-to, but a friend asked us to meet him here, so away we went. Let me tell you, that crust? Like unicorns and pixie dust magic. Like glory and praise Jesus, Hallelujah. Place was packed, and still only waited about 30 minutes for a table. Beer selection was ok, but honestly, I'd drink my own sweat if I had to to have another piece of that pizza.
I really enjoy their deep dish! Super flavorful and you can add many toppings unlike other strict pizza places. Try your deep dish Hawaiian style with Canadian bacon and pineapple. Yum!!
The best deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down. Be prepared for a long wait but it is worth it.
Excellent pizza.  This place is better than pizanos in my opinion. A good tip for the thin crust pizza is to get a side of marinara sauce.  It's delicious

Really good deep dish, but I didn't think it lived up to the hype or was the holy grail of deep dish like some Yelpers made it seem out to be. The pizza tasted like any other ol' deep dish pizza until you get to the crispy, burnt crust, which was indeed delicious, but not really a deal maker in my opinion. I did really like that they heaped on the toppings (pepperoni, mushrooms, and olives) and thought that the cheese/sauce ratio was perfect. My table also ordered the appetizer sampler, which was yummy because we were starving, but nothing special (besides the jalapeno poppers which were gross and filled with Cheez Wiz type cheese). Like other Yelpers have said, the service here is definitely lacking. My friend pre-ordered the pizza at 7 PM and said we'd be coming in at 7:45 PM and the waiter rudely asked my friend to call back at 7:15 PM to place the order since the pies take 30 min. My friend then just suggested that they just write down our order and put it in at 7:15, which thankfully they agreed to. This kind of left a bad taste in our mouths, especially since the pizza wasn't ready until about 8:15 anyways.Overall, I think Pequods is a place that everyone who likes deep dish should try, but don't expect it to be out of this world if you've eaten a lot of deep dish because it's not much different from other good pizza joints (e.g., Lou Malnati's, Ginos East).

If you only have time to try one pizza place in Chicago, I highly recommend Pequod's. Definitely worth the trip from downtown. Between Lou's, Gino's and Giordano's, I thought Pequod's tasted the best. Their crust differentiates them from the rest. It is most like what a real pizza should taste like. It is crispy, but not dry and it actually has a flavor to it. The others are tasteless and like biting into a brick.Pizza is absolutely delicious and this Italian thinks their Italian Beef is excellent as well.

Living in New Hampshire now, there is not much food wise we miss more than great Chicago pizza..   Pequod is a banner example of all that is truly superb about pizza. So glad we had time to stop in and enjoy. We'll be back the next time we come home!!!!

I love Pequod's pizza. I always take out-of-towners here if they ask to experience some Chicago deep dish. The wait can be long but it is worth it. I usually don't like sausage pizza but their sausage is delicious.Salads also good.

My first Chicago deep dish pizza! I didn't realize Pequods is so highly rated - love my cousins for taking me here.It was a Tuesday night, seemed like a medium size crowd. No wait. I believe we ordered pepperoni, sausage, mushroom, and green pepper on a pan pizza. It took a noticeably long time for the pizza to get to our table, but it was worth the wait. It tasted fresh, filling, and scrumptious. I don't think it's something I could eat too often, but it's definitely a good meal.Great deep dish pizza experience, even with the long wait. Seems like a great casual spot.Can I still go back to regular pizza after this?

You can't say enough about this pizza. It is always awesome. Consistently great quality. Good service. This place does everything but work off the excess calories. If you haven't eaten here, you must...
We waited a long time to get our food and my drink was never refilled. As for the pizza itself, it's the best pizza I've ever had in my life!

Can't go wrong with the lunch special for around $5.00. Good solid flavor, some people complain about crust but the crust to typing ratio is atl balanced. A must try for any friends or family in from out of town or first date.

One of my new favorite deep dish pizza spots. I've been to Giordano's, Gino's East, Lou Malnati's, and now this one and Gino's East will be my "go-to" places for pizza on my Chicago trips.The wait wasn't terrible - on a Saturday evening, we had a party of 8 call ahead to be put down on the list, and we waited for 5-10 minutes when we got there. Much better than the lines at Gino's East, and I love the fact that you can call ahead of time to get put on a "priority list" for faster seating when you get there.As an appetizer, we got wings which were pretty unmemorable, and a fried sampler assortment ($8.95) of mushrooms, mozzarella sticks, zucchini sticks and jalapeno poppers. Everything was fried in the same batter, so it was pretty much a guess as to what you were actually eating until you put it in your mouth. I liked the deep fried mushrooms that I had, but I like most deep-fried things. The Cheesy Garlic Bread ($3.95) is just okay. Save your carbs for the pizza. Ditto on the salad - it was good and made us feel slightly better about carb-heavy dinner, but it was nothing to write home about.The pizza on the other hand was phenomenal. The crust was crispy and not soggy in the middle; the tomato sauce was the right proportion and the amount of cheese was just right. I loved both the pepperoni pizza and the sausage & spinach pizza that we got. I think less toppings is more when it comes to ordering, so that the toppings don't completely overwhelm the crust, tomato, and cheese.
